The food was fantastic! If you are looking for a fancy place, this is not it! There is only one tiny bathroom which you have to walk through the kitchen to get through, the Decor and interior is not five stars at all. But they have Italians working there who cook some real Good Italian food. 

The space is small and I kept bumping elbows with the guy next to me. This is a cozy, quick service, delicious restaurant I would stop at after a work out or a long day and just need a chill place to relax and get great Italian!
author: Tergel P.

description: Sat at the bar, enjoyed our knowledgeable waiter who let us try some wines. We both ordered gnocchi. It alleges to be homemade, it was so-so. Tiny portions! The bruschetta was delicious. Great friendly service, average food, awesome wines.
author: Jane R.

description: Amazing food and wait staff. Very friendly. Would give it a 5 Star rating if it weren't shoulder to shoulder dining-wise.
author: Eric B.

description: I don't know how Jack does it, but he has always had a great team and they stay for a long time. Combined with the consistently great food, this place is a winner.
author: Robert M.

description:
Parking - It's SF, it wasn't easy. 

Service - Server was nice

Seats - Had to sit at the bar because we didn't make a reservation. The bar seats were pretty uncomfy. 

Food - 
(Appt)
Calamari - Very good, lightly battered, crispy, and not too oily. 

(Main) 
Contadino Misto - It has sausage and roasted chicken with potatoes, garlic cloves, mushrooms, bell peppers, and etc. The sausage and chicken were still tender. The garlics were delicious. Love the mushrooms in there. The whole dish was sorta lack of taste though. 

Pasta - I can't remember which pasta I ordered except it was in a red sauce and it there were sausage. I didn't like it at all. I had one bite and threw the rest away. 

Probably won't come back.
author: Pauline N.

description:
After overlooking this spot for months I decided to take word-of-mouth advice over Yelp reviews to check it out and have not been disappointed with that decision since! This quaint neighborhood gem offers a refreshingly short bill of fare, my favorites being:
 -- Bruschetta: Clearly fresh, delectable, and better yet complimentary
 -- Carpaccio di Zucchini: Simple yet flavorful combination of julienned zucchini, toasted almonds and shaved pecorino. I've been making it for dinner guests ever since first try and its always been a hit (there's actually a quick video on the site on how to DIY :] )
 -- Tortellini: Ultimate Italian comfort food and guilty pleasure. Meat filled tortellini with mushrooms, and prosciutto, luxuriantly topped with mozzarella and parmesan cheeses mmm
 -- Pesce Fra Diavolo: Red Snapper sauteed in delicious spicy tomato sauce.
 -- Chicken and Sausage alla Diavola

Service was personal and environment inviting, also not a bad spot to grab a glass of wine!
author: Mahsa K.

description: This is seriously one of my favorite places to eat. wonderful food, service, and cozy atmosphere
author: Sara C.

description:
Nice little Italian restaurant on Fillmore that seems to be the go-to neighborhood 
Itallian restaurant. Complimentary bruschetta was very tasty and is a great way to start a meal. I got the calamari with garlic aioli which was delicious although the calamari was a little soggy. I also got a giant rib eye which was seasoned well and very aromatic with a medley of herbs but was overcooked slightly. Overall it is a neat restaurant with good service and hospitality.
author: Ed L.

description: It's been ages since I've eaten here, and had dinner here with family a few weeks ago.  I was pleasantly surprised that the food and service were excellent. Our waiter (wish I could remember his name but he had a beard and was just so nice!!!) and the kitchen were very accommodating with the children's dinner - very impressive and such a relief!  The artichoke with pancetta and the zabaglione were still as amazing as ever.
author: Louise V.

description: Very cool atmosphere, and absolutely delicious food! I really enjoyed sitting and eating at the bar, too. Service was very fast - we couldn't believe how quickly our meals were brought to us!
author: Angela F.

description: Last night we had a delicious birthday dinner here.  What a wonderful meal.  The meal started with some wonderfully tasty bruschetta.  So good.  Then it was difficult to pick a main course, because they all looked so good.  I finally settled on the  shrimp pasta which was a great pick.  I tasted everyone else's meal at the table and nobody left disappointed.
author: P. C.

description: I usually love this restaurant, delicious food and decent service. My last visit convinced me this place is best for casual walk-in dinners. I made a reservation a week in advance for a group of 7 and they put us at a 4-top, I asked if they had table extenders - no, could we switch tables - no. We barely had room for our plates. The service was terrible on this occasion! And our server still tacked on an 18% tip despite his attitude, the teeny table and the power going out for the duration of our meal.
author: Emilie B.

description: Bummer since I can walk to them! Haven't been back after getting a bad bout of you know.. Every time I ate here I had a upset stomach! I eat at other fine restaurants and do not have trouble. And I love Italian food! Ooo well! It's a mystery to me?
author: Kirk M.

description: Went to dinner with another couple on a Saturday night, had to wait for a table despite a reservation but was pretty timely. Complimentary bruschetta was yummy. I tried the salad (basic) and the fried cheese as apps.  Both were delicious.  Split the spaghetti carbonara (no bacon) and the pesto ravioli with my friend and again, both were really well done especially the pesto.  They easily substituted mushrooms for the potatoes.  We all shared the chocolate cake but I wasn't a huge fan of it.  But great quality food and nice service.  Very crowded after 30 years, that says something!
author: Manisha S.

description:
I'd give the food a 3-3.5 stars, but the service really kicked it up to a 4!

Jackson Fillmore Trattoria has been on my ever-growing list of restaurants to try, and though i've lived in the 'hood for 3+ years, i hadn't had the opportunity to dine there until sunday.  It was a beautiful afternoon which gave way to fog and a sweeping chill - classic San Francisco summer, right?

It's one of those unassuming places you walk past because the signage is discreet and the restaurant front is narrow.  The wind blew me into the narrow but long restaurant and I was instantly enveloped by warmth.  I was immediately greeted by the host who assured my date and I we'd be seated shortly.  Led to our table by our friendly waiter, it wasn't long before we decided what we wanted for dinner.  Thankfully the menu isn't ridiculously long, which helped us narrow down our choices in short order.  We both opted for the zuppetta di pesce and the waiter recommended wines for our entrees - a nice sparkling white for him, a nice barbera from piedmont for me.

After taking our menus away, complimentary bruschetta was placed on the table for us to nibble before our food came.  It was a nice slice of toasted bread, liberally doused with olive oil, with chunks of tomato, crushed garlic and basil.  A great way to start the meal!  I liked the barbera our waiter recommended as well.  Medium bodied, fruit forward and grapey.  It wasn't complex, but didn't need to be for the zupetta.

We both enjoyed the zupetta!  It was a generous amount of food, with plenty of shrimp, mussels, and a firm white fish.  There were a few mussels that didn't taste quite fresh, but overall the dish was tasty with the chunks of herb stewed tomato chunks.  It was simple food done well.

What was more impressive than the food was the service.  Great service ALWAYS elevates a dining experience, and our server, who mentioned we were his last customers before leaving to pursue a music career in LA, was excellent!  He came by often enough to ensure we were enjoying our meal, but not so often it felt like we were being constantly interrupted.  I'm just sorry that he won't be there the next time I go, but the wait staff in general seemed to be really nice and friendly, so I'm looking forward to going again!
author: Janet L.

description: The service is excellent. They have also made perfect wine recommendations after listening to what I was looking for. The service also does not feel rushed and we enjoyed a lovely dinner there. The food is quite excellent. We've been back multiple times!
author: Eggert B.

description: Cozy neighbored spot with delicious food and a lively atmosphere.  If there's only two of you I recommend grabbing a spot at the bar.
author: Rachel G.

description: Best restaurant I've been too in a while. The food is superb, the atmosphere is home like. Our waiter was very nice and guided us through the menu and wine list perfectly. Make sure you leave a little room for desert. We have no complaints at all and definitely coming back to enjoy the great food. Ps. Ask ur waiter about their authentic Italian desert (I can't remember the name of it at the moment) but it was like eating a piece of heaven.
author: Bruna S.

description: Authentic and tasty Italian. Great homestyle food and atmosphere. Price is just right, portions are great size. The spaghetti amatriciana is a no brainer and very authentic if you're undecided. Love it
author: Ryan H.

description:
Nice hole in the wall neighborhood Italian restaurant.  Small and can get crowded.  They are always changing the menu and have interesting specials.  I had the tuna with arugula which was fantastic (besides the avocado being to ripe)  Also had the appetizer sampler which was tasty as well.  Service was fast.

Most of the food on the menu is rich and heavy with cream and cheese.  I wish they had some lighter options.
author: Tashie P.

description: Wine, service, food, all delish, highly recommend and I'm from Chicago and we know great Italian!
author: Paula S.

description:
The salmon pasta special (rigatoni, salmon and white beans in tomato based sauce) was the perfect size for me (~4 ounces of pasta) but left my two guy friends starving. You know the servings aren't big enough when you can devour 3 chocolate chip cookies and a large scoop of ice cream after the meal. The three of us each ordered a pasta dish and shared two appetizers (fried goat cheese and filet mignon special). Each appetizer was probably two bites. The wine list was short but had some good choices, Montapulciano, Chianti, and Cabernet to name 3 of the half dozen reds available. 

If you are lazy and don't feel like cooking Sunday night this is the perfect place to go if you live in the neighborhood. Really, small, casual and cozy place with lots of options. Sit at the counter order a nice glass of wine and try one of the specials (the mushroom and white corn risotto special sounded quite appetizing but salmon won in the end). You really have to look for the place since the outside looks ghetto. I probably passed the restaurant a million times while walking up and down fillmore. I probably wouldn't recommend this place if you are very hungry and want to gorge down a big serving a pasta. I also don't recommend this place for those looking for a nice restaurant to bring out of towners. But overall the experience was decent. A bit loud due to the small space and sitting at the counter made it difficult to chat but it was entertaining  to watch the cooks in action.
author: Debbie C.

description: crowded, popular, a neighborhood favorite of exquisite Italian meals. Unique, but not always a top class. Why not come here for lunch, it is rarely occupied, but  on cold winter rainy nights and even regular nights this place is packed and steaming. The Italian wines are authentic, but okay tasting, however, while you wait for your seat ordering a glass of wine, now that really cheers you up a great deal, as waiting line can get frustrating in this crammed space. Tapa-style food is available at the counter. Flavorful but not necessarily fresh. If you like heavy flavors, this is a good place to seek
author: Dilys S.

description: Fabulous place, food and atmosphere. Everything on the menu is delicious, OBSESSED with the zucchini salad. Also, Casey is fantastic.
author: Clare R.

description: Love Jackson Fillmore! Great neighborhood spot.  Delicious pastas.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Awesome! Christian and his staff took care of a large party of over 20 including 8 teenagers and everyone left very happy, beat tomato and Burrata I have ever had.  Fantastic pasta and reasonable pricing especially for the city.
author: M S.

description:
This restaurant is fabulous. There was a long wait when we went here on a Saturday evening, but we were lucky enough to get seating at the bar. After we ordered wine, they served us Bruschetta, which was amazing. The tomatoes were very fresh and the olive oil tasted great. Next, we ordered the Mozzarella Fritti which came breaded in a great tomato sauce which we devoured quickly. For our entrees we ordered the Gnocchi Gratinatti & Linguini Fra Diavolo, both dishes tasted great!

Overall, his restaurant is great not only for it's great Italian food, but also for it's cozy, neighborhood atmosphere which is tough to find in San Francisco these days. I'd definitely come back here again!
author: Thomas A.

description:
Tortellini al forno. Oh my gosh so good. 

We also had the fantasia di ciocolata for dessert which was amazing as well. 

Went on a Friday night without reservations and sat at the bar, which I didn't mind at all. 

Definitely coming back.
author: Allison R.

description:
Living only 3 blocks away from Jackson Fillmore is a big perk of my neighborhood. It's a quaint Italian place, and the food is all very fresh. The owner is extremely friendly and does his best to accommodate large parties.

You HAVE to get the tortellini. I would say that most of their dishes are above average, but the tortellini is the best tortellini I've ever had. I've had it many times there so I know it's not a fluke.

Also, they give you a piece of free bruschetta with every meal. Score!
author: Kevin H.

description:
Cozy, family-run restaurant with solid Italian food.  
Bruschetta - delicious!
Carpaccio de zucchini - also delicious!
Ensalata primavera - incredibly fresh and lightly seasoned - perfect.
Asparagus Ravioli pasta special - alright...a little bland.

The restaurant is really small, so definitely call ahead and reserve a table.  The service was excellent - friendly and attentive.  Our waiter was very knowledgeable about the wine list and menu options.

Overall, a lovely experience for a decently-priced Italian dinner.
author: Lauri C.

description:
Jackson Fillmore is awesome. In terms of food it is nearly flawless. Your pretty classic, clean San Franciscian Italian food without a lot of flare but with some nice subtle awesomeness. Even the fra diavolo sauce won't smack you in the face but it always has big flavor.

I've got to tell you though that in seven years the ambience hasn't changes: It's either nice and local with tons of different types of people from different places of cultures, or it's a mass of people eyeing each other, smacking into each other and talking on top of each other. And not in that fun way--in the "why is my reservation not enogh to get me seated on time" or "listen to me I'm so important" kind of way. On weekends you're just going to get this.

But if food what you're about and you're good at ignoring annyoing people you will love this place.
author: Paul C.

description:
lost a step.  Used to be a reliable spot for pasta and salad. casual and affordable

still casual and affordable, but can't keep pace with delfina and spqr in the neighborhood
author: nick g.

description:
SPOILER ALERT:  Another Great Night at Jacks

I was meeting a colleague for supper on our way over to Yoshi's to see the Jazz Crusaders.  My very first thought was Jack's on Fillmore.  My wife and I used to hang out there A LOT a few years back but things changed and we moved closer to Polk Street yadda yadda...

Anyway, I was on the #23 approaching Jack's at about 8p last Saturday -- there were perhaps 10 or 12 really stylish folks waiting to get in -- a very good sign.  Getting off the bus I bumped into my bud and we threaded our way in the front door.

Jack was helping out table #1 -- the big one in the window .  Now everyone knows that Jack is EXPERT on Italian and Spanish wines -- I heard him doing his thing while we hung out.

A few minutes later he "created" a two-top and we sat down.  The place was buzzing with conversations, food, wine, and just a very nice atmosphere.  We could see the wait staff "sailing" around the room with steaming plates.

I ordered a Prosecco (naturally) and didn't even look at the menu.  The bruschetta came out -- Jack's amouse bouche -- such a nice touch but can be tricky, right?  The tomato/garlic melange is just perfect here -- another good sign.

 knew I wanted Jack's famous Julienne  squash w/ almonds and peccorino -- you know the dish from Jack's youtube video.  It came out promptly and did not disappoint.  I ordered another Prosecco to go with my salmon.  Has anyone but me noticed the salmon this year is spectacular?  The dish came out perfectly executed:  salmon over greens -- so simple but so good.

Finished off with some Escencia and then off to Yoshi's.

NOTE TO SELF:  Need to get back to Jack's more often -- amazing kitchen, great atmosphere, easy on the wallet -- and, of course, Jack in the house.
author: steven s.

description:
Long wait for food....tortellini a forgo overdone (crusty  cheese top), Gnocchi gooey.
Was expecting more judging from reviews.   Sorry....but telling like it is. Lawrence S.
author: Lawrence S.

description:
Jackson Fillmore is a:
A) -- 1970's folk rocker raised in privilege on Martha's Vineyard but burned out by the time he became a Top 40 symbol of the faux-counterculture.
B) -- tax-swindling realtor somewhere in the suburban bowels of Marin County.
C) -- fun trattoria in Pac Heights.

Here is a multiple choice question I would have surely gotten wrong had I not casually strolled on the upper Fillmore one day. The throngs of waiting customers have always intimidated me to venture inside in the past, but a thoughtful friend organized a festive dinner there this past Tuesday. We were seated at the front table where a random designer purse would butt against the back of my head with the fury of an ignorant drone with a bad dye job.

Alas, I overlooked the crowd and escalating noise levels because the food is so damn good here, especially if you are a fan of Italian country dishes. First off is the complimentary bruschetta, which is no little Wheat Thin with a dollop of ketchup. No, no, my paisano...it's a hefty piece of grilled sourdough toast piled high with a marinated chopped tomato mixture. It was such a treat to get right off the bat with no questions asked. Then we segued to their signature appetizer, the $8.50 Zucchini Carpaccio, which easily serves two. It consists of julienned zucchini mixed together with sliced almonds, slivers of pecorino cheese and a twist of lemon. Yummy and dare I say healthy.

I went for the big guns on my entree, the $27.50 Veal Chop, which was incredibly tender covered with sprigs of fresh sage, rosemary and thyme and accompanied with a hefty serving of garlic mashed potatoes. It was so good I named it...Foxy Brown...yep, that's what I named it. The waiter was a bit on the curt side, but we were forewarned - so our expectations were actually exceeded in this case. The crowd subsides around nine-ish if you don't mind going all European in your dining habits. And with good friends, it is so worth the wait.

FOOD - 4.5 stars...loved the specialty dishes...hearty, peasant fare gussied up for the affluent Pac Heights crowd
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...little loud, little crowded but hey, it's all part of the scene here
SERVICE - 3 stars...nothing stellar on this end, but the food came on a timely basis
TOTAL - 4 stars...definitely go for the food and do go with friends who live to eat, not eat to live
author: Ed U.

description: I really enjoyed the food at Jackson Fillmore, especially the Tortellini Al Forno. It was really delicious. Like many restaurants in the city it is very crowded which of course speaks to its great food but it definitely is often quite noisy but still I had a lot of fun and enjoyed every bite of it.
author: Lisa L.

description:
This place is always crowded for dinner time, especially on a weekend. We've shied away from this place for so long because of this. 

They will let you order wine and drink it while you stand around and wait for a table.

As appetizers we ordered the sauteed mushrooms and they topped Cheesecake Factory's stuffed mushrooms on my list. (I'm not a huge fan of mushrooms, so I do not have separate lists for stuffed/unstuffed mushroom) Complimentary bruschetta is always a plus!
author: Jane N.

description: This is a neighborhood favorite, we come at least once or twice a month and are never ever disappointed! The staff at Jackson Fillmore go above and beyond to make things wonderful! We bring family and friends at any chance we get and love to show this place off!
author: Amber B.

description:
Went here on a date around 9pm on a Saturday night and the place was packed!  Seemed to be a popular place for groups of friends to get together and have a meal.

I wasn't starving so we both got their avocado salad and split a pasta dish with shrimp.  The salad was perfection and the pasta was cooked so al dente I almost swooned!  Haven't had pasta cooked like that outside of Italy - it was fantastic.

Tried the Portuguese sparkling wine and loved it so much I had 2 glasses (and I never have 2 glasses of wine!).

The service was fantastic - very attentive and friendly.  Only downside is that it was super noisy.  But I didn't mind - it was a Saturday night after all!

Would love to go back.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I've been here before, the food was great, the service was great, and the wine was even better...
This time around, my pasta wasnt cooked all the way (it was chewy-almost too al dente) my mom's seafood risotto was warm, for some reason we were not allowed to sit at a 4 top, but instead had to wait (even though I made reservations for 6:30p) for the host to bring out a table, and set it up in the middle of the isle, next to a 4 top that would be filled with two people who were extremely obnoxious an hour later. This was nothing in comparison to the way they were in such a hurry to get us out (even though we were one of 4 tables eating). My favorite part of the evening was when an older couple came in (who seemed friendly with the manager/owner) and had to wait about 20 minutes for a 2 top to finish eating before sitting down...

After we paid and were half way down Fillmore, the manager/owner came out to thank us, yelled it at our backs, and made sure to tell us we need to come back soon...what does that tell you?!
Like I said, I've been here before, the food was awesome, the service was great! Maybe they were having a bad night?
author: Jarrod R.

description: Love it. Always have, probably always will.  Every dish is delicious - esp the bombolotti. Any salad (perfectly dressed ever time), desert etc. just go there!
author: Whitney H.

description: Not what it used to be.  My wife's pasta was undercooked rendering it hard and chewy, instead of al dente.  My tortellini was cooked instead of lightly browned in the broiler making it dry and hard, this disappointing in a dish I had come to repeatedly enjoy over the past twenty plus years.
author: Stephen K.

description:
You know that period of time that falls in between when you are seated at your table for dinner and when a waiter takes your drink order, or hell, even acknowledges your presence?  Well, you shouldn't really notice it.  It should not be excessive enough to stick out in your mind.  That is what I remember most about my experience at Jackson Fillmore. 

The Caesar Salad was decent to start.  I had the Bombolotti with veal and "spicy" sausage for my entree.  My taste buds searched for flavor, but left empty handed.  They also couldn't detect any spiciness in the sausage either.  The sauce and the noodles didn't get along very well together.  I think they met for the first time right before they came to my table.  Introducing the sauce to the noodles ahead of time and letting them get to know each other will make for a much less awkward relationship.

I can't say that I would go back.
author: Adam B.

description:
A very fun place, run by Jack from NJ, who is a fabulous host.
Food is 3 to 5 star, depending on what you order, and the price is reasonable. A great casual place anytime.
author: Craig L.

description:
Not sure why folks seem to like this place.  Perhaps I came on an off nite?

Food - eh, it was ok.  I wouldn't even go so far as saying it was delicious.  It was just ok, not bad, not good either.

Ambiance - not great - their vent systems don't work so well so it gets really steamy in their to the point the windows fog up.  Not nice.

Bottom line - if my friend choose to dine here, I would take a raincheck for another get together cause I would not want to spend my money here.
author: Lev E.

description:
Delicious italian, laid back decor

Tiramisu, primavera. with calamari.... Divine
author: Jade H.

description:
Pasta is so easy to cook at home, I seldom go out for it.  Jackson Fillmore is one of the few restaurants in town where it's worth ordering pasta out.  Really, really tasty pasta.

They also have excellent staff.   Last Sunday, they had an unexpected rush due to concerts in the neighborhood, and our table wasn't ready on time ... so we got free wine.  Then when we sat down I asked our waiter for "something red I haven't had before" and he delivered.

Do be warned that it's a tiny restaurant, and is crowded and loud, and they can have trouble seating people on time because it's so small.  That's the reason for four starts instead of 5.  

Do order:
* zucchini carpaccio
* fried goat cheese
* gnocchi
* zabaglione
author: Josh B.

description: Went here tonight on a recommendation of a friend.  Overall this place was amazing.  Nice Italian wine selection, and the food was great.  I had the pollo siciliana which was amazing.  Lots of flavor and just perfectly cooked.  Our server was friendly and all the other staff was very helpful as well.  I did knock it one star as decor/setup was a little strange, if it wasn't for the fact I was told it's been around for years, I would have thought it as an old sushi restaurant.  That being said I will for sure be returning.
author: Melissa K.

description:
I came here a while back with a few friends. The front of the restaurant wasn't impressive, and for this reason it may turn potential customers away immediately, but we went in anyways. The inside was small, and quaint. It seemed like the staff was all one big Italian family wanting to keep their guests happy-- I really liked the family vibe I got from this place.

We ordered some wine and our entrees. They brought out some complimentary bruschetta which was phenomenal. We also ordered the fried mozzarella appetizer which was also to die for. I ordered a tortellini dish with mushroom and pancetta cream sauce. It was one of the richest, most delicious Italian dishes I have ever had in my life. My friends dishes all looked amazing too. They ended up all trying mine and saying it was the absolute best, but I'm sure no matter what dish you order, you will be pleased!

The only complaint I have about this place was that they screwed up our total and charged us for an extra glass of wine that we didn't order. We didn't realize this until walking out of the restaurant, and after paying, so we weren't about to go back inside and complain. I ended up spending about $36 for my dinner + wine which seemed a little bit pricey considering my meal itself was only ~$16. And I KNOW I didn't drink that much wine. Oh well, I'll just have to pay more attention next time around. That little mess up isn't going to keep me from coming back to this place.
author: Ashley D.

description:
My girlfriend thought this was a bakery! I walked in and called her to come down from Broadway. We arrived about 5:45 and the place was already filling out. Combination of take out and dine in. Started with the cheese platter which was great. Pasta course next -Tortellinis which had a creamy white sauce. After two bottles of Chianti, we were feeling great. 
Met the owner who made us feel welcome. 

This may be our new favorite place. Who needs to go to North Beach!
author: Mark W.

description:
I came here with my family on a Friday night, which would have been a mistake, but my aunt called in earlier to hold a table. MAKE SURE TO CALL AHEAD OR ELSE YOUR ASS WILL HAVE TO WAIT FOR GOD KNOWS HOW LONG. Our waiter was great, but he refused to make eye contact with me as if I was the kraken or some horrendous piece of ugly STD virus that would scar him for life. Seriously. 

Anyways, we received complementary bruschetta which was good. We also had two orders of the burrata which was served with mushrooms and a crostini. I feel that this was an overpriced appetizer for a small portion of buratta, but a shitload of mushrooms. I ate it up anyways because wasting that dish would be like walking away from a ten dollar bill that's on the sidewalk.

My main course was this sausage and ragu dish, which wasn't bad, but I wouldn't be lauding it as a great dish either. I couldn't get over the fact that there were a lot of mushrooms on my plate. I don't hate mushrooms, but damn, what gives?! For four people, two appetizers, four main entrees, the bill came out to be 130 bucks including tip. Thank the lord above that I didn't have to pay, but even with all the complaining that permeates this review, I'm glad I tried this place.
author: Lauren L.

description:
Suck, suck suck.  This place sucks.

My husband and I were so excited to potentially find a new neighborhood place when we moved to Pac Heights last year.  We made reservations to ensure a table and *yay* walked to dinner, with 5 minutes to spare.  

Here's where I gush about how warmly we were welcomed, and how we were seated quickly and given menus.  Any other review, yeah, probably.  Not this one.  

The guy at the host stand - who was on the phone with a blatantly personal call - sort of flicked his eyes at us and proceeded to finish his call.  We were rudely received - treated like we were an imposition and taking his precious time for personal calls - and told we had to wait for a table to open up....when there were at least three tables open with set ups.  Another couple came in and were seated before we were.  Without reservations.

Hello?

I realize we weren't "regulars" there and therefore don't deserve special treatment.  But if I'm going out and spending money at your establishment, you damn well better treat me and my husband with a little respect.  Especially when the food was mediocre and the place is nothing to write home about.  Overall, underwhelming.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Jackson Fillmore is fantastic.  
That's as simply as I can put it.  The atmosphere is energetic and only outdone by the food.  My wife and I went there on a Friday, and we both ordered specials: risotto and tortelli.  We are going to go back as soon as we can to try more food.  
Our waiter was also great.  He knew the menu and wines and had a good personality.
Highly recommend.
author: Stuart V.

description: This place is a cool spot for a dinner date. It's also great with friends. Nice variety of pasta dishes. LOVE the complimentary bruschetta appetizer. Such a nice touch! My hubby is lactose intolerant, and the server was fabulous about it. He gave such great advice on what entrees to order with his diet restriction. We'll be back!
author: Valerie A.

description:
I recently had one of those epic dinners with my family that we will all talk about for years. The ten of us (including my mom, my dad, my dad's current wife, and my two year old) were crammed into a table for 8. That ended up making it a lot of fun, since everyone could be in on the conversation. It was the ultimate Italian comfort food: gnocchi covered in cream and cheese, mushroom ravioli in mushroom broth, fish in rich tomato sauce. We all started with bruschetta dripping in olive oil and covered with ripe tomatoes. The wine (Spanish, in honor of the recent World Cup champions) was fantastic. Our server was a total character and managed our rowdy group expertly. You can tell he's the kind of guy who's made a career out of it.

I am a hero in the family now for taking us all there.  Even though the place isn't exactly a secret, it's not much to look at from the outside (ok, or even the inside) but it exudes warmth and comfort and fun. There's nothing cutting edge going on with the food, but sometimes that's just not what you're looking for. I will make a point of going back next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Mandy M.

description: What happened to the Jackson Fillmore I used to go to? It used to be fresh, well seasoned, good Italian food. Now it's cold  (reheated) fried mozerella, over-cooked pasta and small portions. End of a good thing, I guess. There are way too 3000406391many other places to eat in SF to bother with this place.
author: Shawn M.

description:
Had a great experience here!

The wait service was friendly and patient.

The food excellent! I had the tomato soup to warm me up from the bitter cold outdoors. Hit the spot. I love that they offer complementary bruschetta. 
I shared the sicilian chicken and the seared tuna over lentils! Mmmmmmm! Both awesome!
I would definitely go back since my friend lives a stone's throw to the joint. Happy and celebratory environment!
author: Maurice A.

description:
Came here for dinner last night and my friend claimed it was the "BEST" Italian food in San Francisco...
hmm maybe I just have high expectations for pasta.  So to start I do love how the restaurant is family owned and its a comfortable family feel when you walk in.  It's a really cute tiny restaurant and everyone who works there are super friendly with each other like they are family.  I really enjoy the cozy environment.
Dinner:
-Started with a complimentary bruschetta- Great starter!  Wished I had more.  Made perfect and with fresh ingredients!
-Carpaccio di Zucchini - nice, light, thinly sliced Zucchini salad.  
-Portobello Arrosto - Great portion.  Really enjoyed the Portobello mushroom.  The mushroom was roasted with the perfect blend of Garlic and herb flavors. This dish really stood out!
-Linguini Fra Diavolo - shrimp pasta with spicy tomato sauce. It was ok.  Just tasted like regular spicy tomato sauce. 

Overall, the experience was ok. My hunt still continues for the best Italian restaurant in SF.
author: Ying F.

description: The food, wine, & service were all excellent. Some of the best Italian food I've had in a long time. My only small complaint is that it was very noisy - definitely not an intimate place.
author: Amanda T.

description:
3.5 stars

I like this place ... nice neighborhood restaurant.

I've read reviews where folks didn't feel well-treated.  Never been my experience, even if it's crowded.  The servers are cool, and Jack always stops by to say hello.  I was surprised to read people had negative experiences.  

The complimentary bruschetta is fantastic! 

For an appetizer we ordered the sauteed mushrooms with burrata.  Pretty yummy.

My dinner - I ordered a risotto from the specials menu.  Meh.  I wasn't bad, but I didn't love it.

My date ordered the tortellini.  Wow.  I could eat that like it's my job!  

I'll go back!
author: brandie y.

description: Not ONLY did they accomodate 12 on a busy Friday nite, when our party was s'posta be 10, the food was divine, zucchini carpaccio, the antipasti and the zabaglione (hot AND cold) were to die for. And the vino recommendations were spot on.  They'll always be at the tip top of my list!
author: Jill K.

description:
I agree with everyone here... THE SERVICE SUCKS A$$!

The BF and I came here on Christmas Eve. The place was pretty packed, but there was nobody in line except for us. THREE different servers walked by us and didnt greet us or ask us how many we had in our party. In fact, they just looked at us and ignored us as if we werent there. We waited around for a good 5 minutes totally ignored. Perhaps we were probably the youngest couple in the restaurant of perhaps we were the only asians... *shrugs*- i'd hate to really think that...

We ended up leaving shortly after and went to Pasta Pomodoro on Union Street where we received way better service and attention.

I am never coming back ever again and would not recommend this place for anyone.
author: M W.

description:
Found this by accident and was pleasantly surprised by the fabulous food.  Really good authentic Italian food. Great flavors, great staff and you come out not feeling over-stuffed.

The owner dropped by while we were and clearly loved what he was doing with the place. Everyone was friendly and folks we talked to had come from miles around to eat there, the place was completely full - what better sign can you get that it is that good?
author: Mark C.

description:
This is a Pac Heights institution that lives up to its lofty word-of-mouth. I'm not sure why the Yelp rating is so inexplicably low, unless a bunch of foodies found the place too "mainstream" to make it into the ranks of solidly good restaurants. For me, I came here with a few friends to celebrate and found the atmosphere and service both fantastic and friendly. This isn't an edgy, new-wave fusion Italian place: it delivers on the classics with only the hint of a twist, but everything is downright delicious.

As to the food, others have noted how outstanding the warm bruschetta is that arrives, unbidden, to your table when you first arrive. I wanted to order an entire plate as my main, but worried that my friends might be a bit judge-y and so regretfully refrained. The zucchini dish, as our waiter told us, has been on the menu for 20 years and is a delicious classic (and I usually hate zucchini!). I got a special, with a roasted quail served on top of some amazing risotto, and it was transcendent. The tartufo dessert was everything you want in an ice-cream, served with a delicious little side of whipped cream.

All in all, solid Italian that won't fail to please. I'm bringing my parents next time they're in town, and am sure that they will love it as much as I do!

Helpful hint: it pays to reserve! We made a reservation a few days ahead, and were whisked right in to a waiting table through the crowd outside.
author: Sarah M.

description: Just moved to the area and found this great restaraunt.  Fantastic wines and some great pasta dishes. A great find.
author: Aaron E.

description:
So fun!  My friend lives across the street so we decided to treat ourselves Friday evening.  I tried to make a reservation but they said they dont take reservations for parties less then 3.  They said for parties of 2 you wont have to wait more then 20 minutes.  I was skeptical.

They were right.  We were seated right away.  The gentleman at the front who seated us was so pleasant.  He made sure we knew what the specials were and told us his favorite dish (the mini meatballs).

Their special wine that was suggested on the menu was delicious and the food was so good.  My friend is thrilled that we found this place (as she can order take-out from there all the time).  Me, I wont be able to enjoy take-away very often but I look forward to returning.

Oh, if you don't see what you want on the menu they say to ask.  It seems they can prepare dishes to order :)
author: Lizzy M.

description:
Had a lovely dinner there last night.  I had heard from a friend of a friend that this place served a solid meal.  Since it's only a few blocks from my new place, I figured I had to check it out.

Even before I got there, I was impressed with them.  I called for a last minute reservation, since my friends decided to make the switch from dinner at the early bird special time to normal people time.  The host was very accommodating in getting us in for dinner.  The decor is simple, but I'm someone who cares more about the food than a trendy atmosphere.  And the atmosphere was perfect for a cozy neighborhood restaurant.

OK, onto the food.  My glass of Verdicchio hit the spot.  The complimentary bruschetta is a nice touch.  Their special appetizer of burrata with heirloom tomatoes was heavenly, but then again, you really can't go wrong with those 2 ingredients.  The fried mozzarella was tasty as well, but again, can you really go wrong with anything that involves frying and cheese?  Along the lines of cheese, I pretty much devoured the gnocchi.  My friend got the tortellini, which was pretty darn good also.  I didn't try my other friend's dish, the fra diavolo, since that's not my favorite dish.  We split a piece of tiramisu, which was solid.  I think I negated my 5-mile run from the day.  Oh well, it was worth it.

I'm loving my new neighborhood and its culinary offerings.  So happy that Jackson Fillmore can be added to my ever-growing list of local go-to places.  I will be back!
author: Danielle B.

description:
It's been 2 years since we relocated from London and each day we bask in the knowledge that we call San Francisco our home.  Friends recently invited us to dine at Jackson Fillmore before taking in a movie and I was simultaneously kicking myself for not partaking in Jackson Fillmore's delicious offering earlier on and warmly pleased to have finally found this little gem.

I commented to Casey, the Maitre d' that evening  that I have rarely supped at a restaurant where everything offered in menu called out to me.  Seriously, do you not find that almost every restaurant has one, two, three dishes on menu that motivate you to question chef's sanity?

I look forward to my next seating at Jackson Fillmore.
author: Jay D.

description: I LOVE this place! It boasts tasty Italian comfort food and friendly neighborhood service. My favorite appetizer is the insalata romana; my boyfriend and I pretty much get it every time we go here.  Some of my favorite dishes are the gnocchi grattinati (the smoked chicken is incredible!), spaghetti alla carbonera, zuppetta di pesce, and when I feel like indulging, the TORTELLINI AL FORNO.  That dish is over the top delicious! If you have room, try their tiramisu; it never disappoints.  The only con about this place is that it's on the small side, so if they're running behind (which is often the case), waiting for your table can be a bit awkward.
author: Amy B.

description:
We had an early mid week dinner reservation for three. To start - the coed bath was dirty even though they were just opening for dinner service. Place soon got packed up (by 6pm!) and the noise level went thru the roof making talking at our table impossible. But we were able to hear the conversation (every painful word) of the unhappy couple seated literally 2inches from us- waiter had to stretch across them to serve our table. I had to inch my way out sideways when leaving  (still overlapped their table) or their table would have had to be pulled out to let me out.
The food is definitely not worth this terrible ambiance and was mediocre at best. Some weird spices and prep- stay away esp from fried mozzarella and the calamari- awful - dense limp greasy and tasted reheated from last week. Pasta dishes again weirdly seasoned and over cooked. Best to avoid this. Cost for 3 no desserts no wine was $110. Not worth it at all.
author: Robyn G.

description: Great Food. Nice quaint homey feel. Food was fresh and delicious. Nothing fancy crazy just some down hoe good ol' Italian cooking, like mom used to make!
author: Ron S.

description:
One of my fav restaurants in the city for great, semi-casual Italian fare. The staff is always friendly and nice and the food (especially the specials) are always delicious. 

Haven't had a bad meal here.
author: Courtney S.

description: Went here with the Family. Was a nice cozy neighborhood Italian place. Very small and the food was decent. Nothing to write home about. I would come here again for another quick Italian dinner.
author: Lauren W.

description: Pleasant Italian place at the top of Fillmore.  We asked the waiter to bring the dishes he recommended, so we tasted a wide variety.  Nothing stood out as amazing, but we enjoyed our meal.  If you go, try the large antipasto plate.
author: Kim K.

description:
This place was OK, but I won't go back. And that's not just because I got food poisoning.

The food was decent but a little too rich for me. The didn't serve us any bread, not even with our pasta, though we did get one piece of free bruschetta each. The guy who sat us was really unfriendly and seemed annoyed that we were there. I don't think he ever looked at us. The waitress was nice.

Oh yes, and the food poisoning. I was up all night puking my guts out. Seriously.  I'm not sure if it was the chicken or the appetizer (a "medley of stuff from the bar" -- the waitress didn't know for sure), but whatever it was wanted to get out of my body immediately by any means possible. Will not go back.
author: Andrew T.

description: Gnocchis taste like my grandma's and the carbonara is absolutely delicious. I recommend this to everyone!
author: Morgan D.

description:
The wine selection was plentiful, and it is cool that they support Best Buddies (nonprofit org) through the purchase of bottles or cases of wine.

I ordered the linguine, which has a spicy kick that leaves your mouth watering for more wine.  I enjoyed the bruschetta, but thought that it was a little oily.  Our server was very friendly, and he made the experience enjoyable.
author: Jenni D.

description:
I'd seen this place a couple of months ago but only made it in tonight for our first visit. We were seated at the bar...right in front of the action. Got menus and saw the specials of the day on a small chalkboard placed in front of us. To our right was a selection of antipasti and to the left was cured meats and cheese. The first special was an appetizer...a caprese. The second option was an entree...a paella but using meats rather than seafood. OK. I'd made my choices.

We placed our orders. I ordered a glass of Cava.  A bruschetta arrived and it was terrific. Uh-oh. There was no way I was gonna be able to eat everything. The caprese arrived with beautiful heirloom tomatoes and fresh mozzarella. Awesome. It didn't last long. It was soon followed by the paella and a glass of Spanish red. The paella had chunks of various meats and had a dollop of sour cream in the center. I was full before I started but I wound up eating more than half of the (generous) bowl. I ended up taking the rest with me...something I rarely do. Dessert was impossible.

Service was great. Ambiance was nice...neighborhood feel. I can't wait to come back.

4.5 stars.
author: Gary C.

description:
AMAZING. Servers were friendly, atmosphere was great. Food was perfect. Great home style Italian food. Favorite is the warm brucetta served while waiting for meal, yumm! Would highly recommend it. 

It is a small place so you might have to wait. Looks like the place has fabulous take out business too.
author: Marissa M.

description: I've had dinner from Jackson Fillmore twice.  The first experience I had was not great.   The Pollo alla Siciliana was nothing special, and swimming in sauce.  I was disappointed with my selection and would have preferred the pasta dish my boyfriend got.  I don't love that their menu doesn't offer a variety of other dishes that don't have heavy cream or cheese (hence why I chose the chicken dish).  The second time I had dinner from here I had the Bombolotti Sugo de Carne.  Not something that blew me away, especially since there was very little meat compared to the sauce and pasta.  To be honest, it seemed like something I could have made myself.  Greg got the same thing I did except he got even less meat and more sauce.  The bruschetta they serve to go with their take out orders only comes with one bread slice for each, which is unfortunate since it's probably one of the better things they serve.  Overall, I wouldn't put this in the top tier of Italian options, especially when SF has so many places to choose from.
author: Lisa I.

description:
This is a quaint little neighborhood italian restaurant with a good small vibe and tasty food. The wine list is a bit expensive but the least expensive bottle was still tasty, the complimentary bruschetta was great and the pastas (the waiter said they were the two most popular) my friend and I ordered were delicious! The serving sizes were a bit small compared to most Italian places with heaping dishes of pasta, but were super tasty so worth it! 

The owner came over and took our wine order and noted that all of the wines on his menu are good (trying to make us feel better about ordering the least expensive wine, still $35), but our normal waiter could have been a bit more vocal. I had to ask about the complimentary bruschetta since I had read about it on Yelp, so not sure if he would have brought it. 

The atmosphere is great  and food is tasty. Perfect date place or catching up with a friend.
author: Rachel G.

description:
Bland. Really bland. I had a green salad and thought it was bland, then out came nice ricotta ravioli, with a bland oily pesto, with boiled potato slices and bland green beans. It was a big plate of soft and bland.

Four stars for very nice service and nice atmosphere, down to three for bland food and down to two for the price.
author: Scott H.

description:
Consider this a concurring opinion to all others re Jackson Fillmore.  The food is good - not great - and the service is bad. 

Consider our experience upon entering: Backstory is that we'd made resos on OpenTable for 2, on a Friday night.  We walk in, along with several other parties of 2 at our reservation time.  The host freaks out, and shouts to all of us that we're not doing ourselves any favors by making reservations on OT, and where was he supposed to seat us - can't we see the restaurant is small (?), and OT "screws" him by letting parties of 2 make reservations "late at night" (8:45) b/c how can he turn people (with no reservations) away if they show up earlier? We were put off by his behavior. 

I had a nice caprese, to start, and ziti - which were both fine. It's a small, neighborhood Italian joint...nothing more.
author: Emily M.

description: Bravo, to you Jackson Fillmore Trattoria for making me feel so at home. It is not often you can find a restaurant that has great food, wine, and still gives you the impression that you are at your in a place close to home. For the food. I've only been twice but everything has been great. The goat cheese antipasto if they have it is to die for. The gnocchi is decadent, and the tortellini al forno can't be beat, i swear its the best i've ever had. I will say the ambiance is kinda quirky, it makes it up in quality and a genuinely good time. I strongly suggest for family regathering and spending time with friends you haven't seen in ages you won't regret it.
author: Sean MC E.

description:
Jackson Fillmore is a great neighborhood restaurant, I'm a complete fan! I'm surprised that so many people say the service sucks, because I usually find the waiters quite nice and attentive.. I guess maybe it is hit or miss.

Most of the dishes are great - but my absolute favorite is the baked tortellini in a cream sauce with prosciutto. my description cannot even do it justice. It's rich and flavorful and the best tortellini in town (and I love tortellini!) It's a great place to go out for dinner, and to me, a reliable place to walk to at night. It might not be the best place in town, but it's consistent, and everyone always ends up happy with their meal when I go. 

I'm leaving town for 6 months, and the night before I leave, I'll be at Jackson Fillmore eating my fair share of yummy italian food.
author: Ashley H.

description: Been coming here for 25 years!!!!  Get the GOA.  Enough said.
author: Beverly C.

description:
Two stars?  Pretty harsh.   Why?  Could it be the somewhat plain room?  Partly.  Could it be the lackluster service?  Partly.  Maybe it was just that nothing particularly did it for me here.  Especially the food, which to me at least seemed undistinguished.  Or maybe I walked in thinking this would remind me of Old New York Italian and it wasn't that by a long shot. 

The food wasn't bad, although for what it was it seemed pricey.   I started with linguini fra diavalo.  Al dente pasta.  Small shrimp and small prawns.  Spicy sauce that was like what you get in the supermarket with some chili flakes added.  Bottled sauce on steroids.  Fried chicken cutlets tasted  only of the oil in which they had been fried. The cutlets were served with a salad that was tasty.  Maybe my memories of old style italian were too fond for this place to live up to.  More likely the food was just so-so.
author: David D.

description:
The place is really small. the food is good, but it is way too expensive!
The service was really bad! My girlfriend is a vegetarian and the waiter looked at her as if she were crazy... she is also lactose intolerant, so he did not want to deal with her at all... Also the portions weren't that big....
author: jaime b.

description: I loved this place. I went with about 8 people. They squeezed us in just fine. The food was made with clean and simple ingredients. I shared orecchiette and the zucchini salad, red snapper with spicy tomato sauce & the tortellini. The first two sounded boring, but they were outstanding. Nice casual but hip atmosphere (obviously...I was there). The wine was good. The dessert was just so-so.
author: Gina M.

description: Excellently crafted, thoughtful Italian classics with a twist.  Service was excellent, knowledgeable, and very eager to make suggestions and wine pairings.  Pre-meal bruschetta was absolutely divine.  We had the Whitefish Diavala (spicy, tangy, succulent meat in a standout sauce), and Asparagus Tortellini.  Mmmm!  Restaurant is small, ambiance comfortable but not opulent by any means.  Solid, neighborhood gem.
author: Rachel A.

description: Great food! The most important part of any place and it's also accompanied by friendly and knowledgeable service. We were suggested a fantastic wine to accompany our meal and it was perfect! Everyone at our table enjoyed their dishes and it provided us a great place to catch up and enjoy our time together. I would highly recommend this place to anyone!
author: Michael D.

description:
Jackson Fillmore Trattoria is a cozy little neighborhood restaurant in the Fillmore District. I recently went there for dinner with two friends. The restaurant's decor is very simple in keeping with the family/neighborhood motif. We were immediately greeted at the door and sat on time for our reservation. A ton of reviews on Yelp complain about the size of the restaurant and the wait for a table. To those people who don't appreciate the cozy friendly neighborhood vibe of this place, you should hit the local Olive Garden. When a restaurant claims they are "cozy", it means they are small, so plan accordingly. 

I ordered the Linguini Fra Diavolo which claims to be "a total Jackson Fillmore classic", but sadly I wasn't very impressed. The sauce was nice, but lacked the spice that I usually find in a Fra Diavolo sauce. I was expecting my mouth to be on fire with the devil, but sadly it wasn't. My friends ordered the Zuppetta Di Pesce and the Polla Alla Noci. The Zuppetta Di Pesce was a hit and my friend was very happy with her cioppino-like dish. The Pollo Alla Noci literally disappeared into my friends stomach in 2 minutes. (I think he liked it.) The dish was a boneless chicken breast covered with mushrooms, walnuts, pine nuts, sherry wine and a touch of cream. It looked delicious. If I wan't allergic to nuts, I would have asked for a taste. The waiter was super friendly in that he noticed my friend inhailed his dish and we were still eating, so he offered to bring him some bread to slop up the sauce. 

I liked Jackson Fillmore Trattoria; however, I don't know if it tops my list of neighborhood pasta joints. The service is friendly and the price is right. My favorite part of the meal was the complimentary bruschetta for the table. I wasn't as impressed with my meal as my friends were with theirs. 

A final positive for the restaurant was that I made a reservation by leaving a message on their voicemail as their OpenTable.com service wasn't working properly. I quickly received a call back which was a nice personal touch by the staff. Too often restaurants don't call you back and assume you will call them again, which is just plain rude.
author: Alice S.

description:
Started with the Antipasto Misto, then shared the red snapper with their famous hot tomato sauce and a risotto on the special menu, with a bottle of Altun Rioja red wine.  The wine was recommended by the host, who I think may be the owner.  It was okay.

For dessert, we ordered the Zabaglione (decadent, refreshing and light) as recommended by another customer sitting by us at the bar.

I gave 3 stars for this restaurant because the food is decent, ambiance is comforting and friendly, other customers were extremely friendly, and the price is reasonable for what it is.  

I would definitely recommend this place and go back again.
author: Carmen C.

description: The food here is spectacular. Just make sure you have a reservation!
author: Julie F.

description: I can't understand the negative reviews submitted by others.  It's the perfect neighborhood spot, high end hole in the wall.  The service was flawless and lacked all pretension,  and the food was delicious and comforting. Many have mentioned the bruschetta, which was a flavor packed start to our meal; but we also had the antipasti starter and every bite was a treat.  The vibe of this restaurant is comfortable and familiar and warm.  Don't go for a big night out, but when you want really good food in a super cozy atmosphere where you feel like people are happy you showed up, go here!
author: Gaylen K.

description: Just fabulous. I had a great cioppino and my dining companions gnocchi and linguine. All were wonderful. I had zabbaglione for dessert and it was excellent. Also excellent was the service and the wine list. We highly recommend it.
author: H. M.

description:
Underwhelming. Everything was bland. I had to season everything myself. The meal started out great with a very tasty complimentary bruschetta.  We started with the antipasti which was very good. Although I question the wisdom of storing a tuna salad in a broken sushi fridge. I'd feel far more comfortable if it was a working sushi fridge. ( As we sat in front of it for nearly three hours and it was never rotated, I'm sure the health inspector would not be pleased. ) Regardless, the tuna salad AND the rest of the antipasti was pleasing. Then we had the insalata primavera. It was Arugula, fresh shelled peas and fava beans, blanched asparagus bits, pecorino etc., but only a cheap olive oil as a dressing. Even using a good quality olive oil would require sone sort of acidity to balance the salad and make a dressing. No salt was added. We had to ask for balsamic and s&p it ourselves.  Then was the catastrophic burata funghi. Bland as could be despite the porcini mushrooms that leached so much water (this happens with frozen porcinis) that the toast beneath is was mushroom water soggy. No salt. Very little flavor. We could not salvage this dish, but the burata itself was delicious. Then we had the spaghetti carbonara, which was good, not great. We had to add s&p, parm and lemon juice to liven it up. Over all, we were far from impressed. 

The service was polite and well intentioned but very slow. It took 30 min. to get our first (wine) order. Our Server was constantly in the weeds, plating cold stuff while customers wait. They'd be better off spending the $100. on labor and turning more tables. We were there nearly two hours longer than intended.
author: Fareed R.

description: This place has the best bruschetta I've ever tasted! A great neighbourhood restaurant. I wish they have more fish and veggie entrees, they tend to have quite a few chicken dishes....Anyway, it's a great place, always slammed, I tend to sit at the bar.  My favourite is green salad with creamy garlic dressing, I could eat boat loads of that! I've had the spaghetti cabonara, it's not bad, and last night I had the Gamba ala Catalana.  It was very good.  The chcocolate torte with the cold zabaglione is to die for and the wines are always great.  The owner who also hosts....well, he doesn't give me the warm and fuzzies.  Mind you, it doesn't seem he did with his 3 ex-wives either but hey, I'm there for the food!
author: Favoloso M.

description: Jackson Fillmore has a very special place in my heart. What is it about this restaurant that makes it a favorite?  Oh yeah....The food is delicious.  The wine is fabulous.  The service is impeccable.  Pollo alla Noci is a personal fave but I can honestly I've never tasted anything here that wasn't to die for.  Roasted artichoke...yummmm.  The tortellini, red snapper, and Calabrese sausage dishes are all perfection!  Need a beautiful wine to pair with your beautiful meal?  Just ask the guy with the awesome beard...his wine knowledge is above and beyond.  He and his sister run the place flawlessly!  I raise my glass to you JF... cheers to the finer things in life that deserve to be celebrated!
author: Natalie M.

description: It's terrible, don't go here.. hahah. I want to keep this a local's joint! Haha, cat's out of the bag. It's off the beaten trail. Awesome Italian food. Wasn't sold on the prosciutto parmesan doughnuts, but cannot go wrong with the chorizo paella and the never-fail tortellini. Excellent syrah mix and  bruschetta was primo. Don't bother with reservations. The locals definitely get special treatment. Skip on the dessert, meals are quite filling. Like the owner and his staff was pretty friendly
author: Naomi K.

description:
It is located away from the beaten path of Fillmore and doesn't look very exciting/attractive from the outside so if my gf had not suggest it, i don't think i would have ever come in.
A large party was finishing up dessert when i came in, it must have been an entire family w/ several generations. It looked like they had a great time so i took it as a reassuring sign.
We proceeded to the table rapidly and had a great heirloom tomato appetizer (fresh, yum!), pasta carbonara (ok) and a fish dish (good) for entrées.  Portions were copious, the food wasn't extraordinary but was nonetheless tasty.
This place must have bee a sushi restaurant before, in the 90's, there's still the typical window fridge all along the bar and nothing has been remodeled since then.  The kitchen isn't the cleanest around.
But overall, a nice, sure bet in the 'hood.
author: Damien J.

description: Incredible food. Given richness and depth of flavor, the portions are perfect and leave you satisfied. Staff is organized fast but engaging. Small space is not so much cramped as it is cozy.
author: Jon A.

description: Just had dinner at this Trattoria. Awful! Came home with the stomach ache from having such oily food. Everything was floating in olive oil and grease. The service was just ok. It took 15 minutes to get a side dish of spaghetti (the waiter was apologetic about it, though). No one explained the specials - they just through a board with them on the table in front of us. Very pricy. Dinner for two with shared appetizer was $80.00, no wine or desert. Was surprised to see them being busy.
author: Andrei A.

description: OMG! The bruschetta they serve is to die for! Love this little joint! I had a lovely heirloom tomato and avocado salad and then a wonderful salmon for dinner. I can't WAIT to come back!!!
author: Natasha M.

description: My favorite Italian restaurant!! Service is great, food is incredible. zucchini carbacio is an unbelieveable appitizer go for it! all the pasta dishes are great!! The staff is knowledgeable and honest, I have gone with there suggestions on wine and always happy!! It is small, and can be hard to get into. The complementary brushetta is a nice touch and tasty!
author: Mike D.

description:
I think the food is tasty and creative.  Zucchini carpaccio!  Pure genius.  And the free bruschetta ALMOST makes up for the rude receptions.  But not quite.

In my experience, everyone who works at this place is nice except the one guy.  Unfortunately, since he's the host, everyone has to meet him.  He must be the owner, or at least a partner, or else he'd be fired by now and working in a more appropriate industry for his skill set.  Like as a collections agent.  Or a lighthouse operator.
author: Rosie W.

description:
LOVE!

The owner is super awesome, helpful, knowledgeable, etc

The food is delish and not too pricey at all, and the wines are priced even better

It gets busy, that's for sure, but so worth the wait!!!
author: Elle L.

description:
I yelp...a lot.  I sometimes even raise my eyebrows when I do not recognize a certain business.  Yet, here it was, a new guy, a second date, a native from San Francisco, saying this place is a San Francisco "classic," and I had never heard of it!  The location is nice, and parking on a Tuesday night was relatively easy.  It is very modest (read, simple, no frills atmosphere) and the service is actually charming, but very direct and to the point.

I had the salmon and potato ravioli in a tomato broth (which was not overly rich, and you could distinctly taste the freshness of the salmon) and he had,  well I don't know...possibly paying too much attention to him.  We did share the artichoke appetizer, which is an entire, h-u-g-e Artichoke and you get to tease each other by ripping the pulp off the skin.  

They honestly have amazing  bruschetta (it is complimentary and has twice the amount of toppings then the bread it was on..."perfect!")  We sat at the bar...next to each other and that was the best.  It feels more personal...he did finish my food without hesitation, but he's like 6'5, 220, so the serving sizes might be a tad small for that kind of appetite.

When asked for desert, of course as this was only the 2nd date, I modestly said, "no I am ok"   and he was like hell no, you have to try this.... "this" was the cold zabaglione.  It is bright yellow and thick, but not overly sweet and the crunch crumbles of cookies mixed in makes it wonderful (as well as the strawberry's that they are very generous with).

One last note, they do not take reservations (well according to other reviews unless you have more than2 people) but you can hold hands and walk in the park across the street while you wait or grab the side-by side seats at the bar.  Yes, it is very "classic."
author: Mai G.

description:
The first time I stepped foot in this place was 'Meet the Parents' night, when her parents drove up from the South Bay for dinner. Being that someone in her family is a chef, she wanted to pick a place that was going to be appealing but not break the bank. 

Although it was uber busy, Jackson Fillmore worked out just fine.

Her Dad and I ordered the same stuff pretty much the whole way through--Spicy Calabrese Sausage & Chicken with Mushrooms, Peppers & Roasted Potatoes. Awkwardly enough, he and I shared a Tiramisu at the end of the meal--I totally could have eaten one on my own...maybe two.

Most recently, she and I went back there for a late dinner & it wasn't quite as busy. Per usual, they gave us the free (and awesome) Bruschetta & I tried the Tortellini with Mushrooms & Prosciutto. 

OOOOOOOHHHHH Man. 
Super yummy.

I saved a little bit & it was one of the first things I thought about when I woke up the next morning. 

I've read reviews about this place before, and people have mentioned the service is lacking--I've never had this problem. The staff acts aloof, but that's not a bad thing. They don't hover & ask you eleventy-billion times, "how you are doing, is everything ok???"...that's the way I like it.

Edit:
It seems after my girlfriend's reading of this review, Jackson Fillmore was not what I was thinking of first thing in the morning.
author: matt m.

description:
Holy packed in like a Japanese subway train!  If you've been lacking physical human contact as of late, you can get your fix here.  Unless you're claustrophobic however, don't let the fact that Jackson Fillmore is space challenged deter you, even if there's a wait.  

I have a test for Italian places --- gnocchi.  I'm a gnocchi addict.  At times, I've had leaden, gluey blobs drowned in a viscous sauce that tried and failed to cover up the crime on my plate.  Chefs who serve this as gnocchi should be forced to take the short bus back to culinary school.  Jackson Fillmore, however, serves gnocchi that are light little pillows of starchy goodness gently caressed by a flavorful sauce with a sprinkling of fresh basil.  Gnocchi Heaven!

Full disclosure: they let us order a bottle of wine while we waited for our table, so I'd been drinking for a bit prior to receiving my meal.  I don't think that impacts my gnocchi experience --- I'm usually drinking before, during and after dinner.
author: Alannah T.

description:
I give this three stars only because the rest of my party really liked their dinners. And our server was excellent. Clearly they operate on a thin staff, and she managed to smile, be positive, constructive and conversational. Did you know the server makes the salads and anti-pasta? They do. And serve half the room.

Now for the food - The anti pasta meat was beautiful, the mixed platter was all disguised. You had no idea what you were eating. It tasted fine, but no stand-outs.

Entrees - Tortellinis were cheesy, Prawns were baby, and shrimp were as tiny as you can get before they become sauce.

I had the Pesto ravioli with potato. Not good. Pesto was really watery, and the potato's undercooked. Must have been rushed to have watery pesto with no salt.

Overall - neighborhood restaurant that has been living on its past laurels for way too long.

Lastly - OWNERS - CLEAN UP YOUR BATHROOM! Can't believe the health department doesn't shut this down. I don't care how old the building is, or how long its been there or how hard the city of San Francisco is to work with. This bathroom is unacceptable.
author: Lola S.

description: Another popular San Francisco trattoria, but this one's been around for a number of years, so you are assured of a reliably good meal.  The atmosphere is bright and lively, with those blue-checked tablecloths, yet very simple, and there is a counter that is convenient when the wait for a table is going to be lengthy.  Great bruschetta, antipasto trays, and baked pasta dishes.
author: Rick H.

description:
Pretty good and fresh fare.  We used to walk here for dinner from many blocks away and in SF with the hills and all...whew.  At least we'd be guilt free after mill working off the food.  Regularly ate here.  Crowded, cramped, and almost always have had to wait.  Once you start noshing on the bruschetta, you calm down from all the wait.  Here are a few samplings of my favorites:

-Complimentary garlicky fresh bruschetta
-Carpaccio di Zucchini - nice, light, thinly shaved raw Zucchini drizzled with warm EVO and almond slivers.
--Linguini Fra Diavolo - shrimp pasta with spicy tomato sauce.  Like the sauce and fresh pasta.
-Pasta Carbonara - one of my favorites.  
-Rotating specials

Flavor of SF
author: I. P.

description:
Jackson Fillmore has been a neighborhood gem for 10+ years and recently they added a deliciously creative Italian tapas selection to their menu.  

My BFF and I went into JF for my birthday this week and we were blown away by the variety of the tapas.  We had seared Ahi tuna in a light cream sauce that blew our minds, followed by a perfectly cooked tapas sized filet mignon steak, and in-season heirloom tomatoes with slightly melted Burrata (fresh Italian cheese made from mozzarella and cream).  Their complimentary bruschetta never fails -- it's the best!  And zabaglione freddo is my favorite dessert.

The owner, Jack, poured us glasses of Cava to get my bday celebration started.  The service, smiles, and warmth I get whenever I go to Jackson Fillmore makes me feel like I'm visiting with old friends whenever I have dinner there.

If you haven't been to Jackson Fillmore in a while, you should definitely stop by and try out their new menu.  It's both an old neighborhood favorite -- and a great new find!
author: Tina T.

description:
Italian food is probably one of the simplest cuisines to prepare. Not because it's easy, but because there are usually very few ingredients in any given dish. The Jackson Fillmore Trattoria did an admirable job at assembling the different ingredients into tasty food. 

I surprised the bruschetta was free. Great way to start the meal. We each had a salad. Mine was the one with mixed vegetables. Too much garlic dressing, still liked the garlic. Really large portion for $9. We could have shared. I had the mixed grill with sausage, chicken, potatoes, and pepper. The Calabrese sausage was as spicy as advertised. The chicken was a little hard to eat because of the bones. Potatoes were fine. Again, huge portions. I only ate half and took the rest to go.

The place has elements of an old diner, but they've added the frills of a cloth napkins, table clothes, and dim lighting.

I would be happy to have given more stars if the place weren't so noisy and the staff had been a little more attentive. Still, it's nice to have a good Italian place in the neighborhood I'm visiting so frequently.

Oh, and I love the waiter trick of dropping off the bill, seeing that you need change and never coming back to collect it until you give up in frustration and leave... great way to ensure a fantastic tip. Next time, I'll pay by credit card.
author: Dave B.

description: Great food.  Would refer to all my friends. It's like a  NY neighborhood local spot.  Sauce was a little spicy but good. Owner has a great sense of humor mixed with a fabulous menu. The Zabaglione was the best I have ever heard in or out of Italy.
author: Gary S.

description:
5 stars for delivering 5 dishes that we all thought were outstanding. Service was pretty good, the place is small & the decor is comfortable, but it was the food that really delivered:

Complimentary Bruschetta - I didn't even count this as one of the five dishes - delicious, and what a great touch. When was the last time you got comp anything besides water & plain bread?

Tuna Crudo - beautiful pink slices of tuna with the right finishes; melt in your mouth

Stuffed Artichoke - arrived at our table piping hot, topped with crispy breadcrumbs & pancetta bits. Yum.

Tortellini - wonderfully satisfying meat-stuffed pasta in a creamy  mushroom sauce, topped with cheese & baked.

Balsamic-Garlic-Olive Oil Chicken - highly recommended; it's a dish I would come back for. Awesome balsamic sauce - flavorful but not overpowering; moist & tender chicken.

Halibut  - w/ spicy tomato sauce. Generous portion of 2 huge fillets cooked perfectly in a robust, spicy but well balanced tomato sauce. 

The only thing I will mention is that the entrees were presented family style (protein only, not accompanied by any sides) - which was not communicated in the menu. We would have liked to have some vegetables or pasta/potatoes to accompany the entrees, but did not see any listings of side dishes on the menu, which is odd.
author: Kathy Y.

description: I love this neighborhood spot. The staff is great and they recommend the best bottles of wine. The bruschetta is so good, and is complimentary. You won't be disappointed with anything you order here!
author: Beth W.

description:
My girl had been wanting to go to Jackson Fillmore for awhile, and tonight seemed as good a night as any.

The first thing that turned me off was the $20 corkage fee. $10 no problem. $15? Maybe. But, $20? Come on.

The brought complimentary brucheta to start, which was great.

Otherwise everything was pretty standard.
author: Jason R.

description:
Cute neighborhood restaurant in Pac Heights. A good mix of classic Italian preparation with CA favorites (prosciutto parm artichokes? ok!). Definitely try the Tortellini if you're on the hungry side. Best to order in classic Italian style [ Antipasta --} Primi --} Secondi --} Dolci ] but can be pricey if you do so. Desserts were just OK except for the coffee, gelato and cream dish whose name I forget. THAT was outstanding. Tiramisu did not. (Tiramisu is Italian for "pick me up".) 

Overall I'd go there again when visiting friends in Pac Heights or when I'm craving non-conventional Italian but might not be the first place I think of when hosting out-of-town guests. Could use a tad more ambiance, especially with the music. Please lose the weird 80's rock (yeah I love the 80's too but trust me this isn't in a good way).

Service was great: we started as a two-some and added one at a time until we had five. They accommodated us with grace and hospitality, bringing each new arrival a delicious, garlicky bruschetta bite right as he / she sat down. 

Thanks for a great meal Jackson Fillmore!
author: Seth W.

description:
This bustling, little restaurant has great food and good (fast, a bit curt, but efficient) service. 
Great selection of wine, but you may want to choose a more exotic bottle due to pricing. Avoid paying double for a bottle you can pick up at the liquor store on the corner.

Good for dates; the busy atmosphere may not be very romantic, but at least no awkward silences can wreak havoc on your chemistry whilst you fall in love. You can talk about your awesome selves while munching on complimentary bread sticks at every table. And, get this, a free serving of BRUSCHETTA while you wait for your order. Excellent.

*The gnocchi continues to hold first place over all the other gnocchi dishes I've had in the city. With really well-balanced flavors of basil, melted mozzarella, alongside the dime-sized potato dumplings, the dish...is...delicious. I drool.

From casual to semi-formal, there's no worries about your attire. Cool.

I'm a fan.
author: Tina J.

description:
___________________________________________
NO DIET COKE ???!!!???

ERROR!!! DOES NOT COMPUTE !!!
____________________________________________
I came here for dinner last night with a friend who has a strong affinity for one of their appetizers.  And, with good reason!  It involves shredded zucchini, freshly grated Parmesan and toasted almonds.  Toasted almonds can make anything tastes good!  I'm not a big fan of zucchini, but shredded I didn't mind it all.  His app was quite good.  Mine was okay, nothing great.  It involved asparagus and portobello mushrooms that were a little tough.

As we were eating our entrees which involved uninspired fried chicken cutlets, our waiter who may have been the owner came by to see if we wanted more wine.  I said no, but I'd like a Diet Coke.  "We don't have anything diet here."  Cute, but not the answer I was looking for.  He rattled off a list of fruit flavored sodas which I declined.  I can't drink wine all the time!
