Sometimes a boy needs his Diet Coke and they were giving me none.  Oh, well.

Overall, it is a very friendly place but the food didn't grab me in any way.  And, I could never take my sister, the Goddess of Diet Coke here.  She'd freak without her nectar!!
author: Jeff P.

description:
Hands down, my most favorite Italian eatery in San Francisco.  

First of all, the location isn't in the quintessential Italian neighborhood of North Beach, so the patron can't help but take notice that there's a touch of extra love and care that goes into every dish.  

Second thing to note, the bruschetta and the ravioli and the tortellini dishes are a MUST!!  Simply put, deliciouso!

I really want to come back here as soon as I can make it happen, for I've just been CRAVING the tortellini here.  What I love the most is how cozy and comfortable and intimate this place is, as if it's largely undiscovered by the masses outside of Pacific Heights (though it's most definitely a popular spot, as you can always expect a crowd on any given night).  

Word to the wise: be sure you secure a reservation prior to your visit, otherwise you may find yourself waiting awhile for a table to open up.
author: Katie C.

description:
We really wanted to like this trattoria.  We like to walk from our hotel on Pacific down to Fillmore, and the Fillmore Grill used to work for us, but this sounded worth a try.  I was able to get reservations at 7:30 for 4 on a Saturday night using Open Table reservations.

It was busy; it was noisy-- several large groups were close to yelling at each other across the small space.  We were seated after a few minutes wait and I think I lost my voice trying to talk across our table within the time it took for the water & bruschetta to come. 

As other reviewers have aptly described the foods, I'll just note that we all enjoyed what we ordered-- tortellini, pasta with seafood, gnocchi, stuffed artichoke (could have been cooked more) and portabella salad. 

The host was just about the most surly, unfriendly one I've encountered.  He looked like he hated his job, disapproved of what we ordered, was ticked off that we didn't order wine ( we'd had wine at our hotel), and that he wished we weren't there.  Probably not true, but it's not a way to have your paying clients/ diners feel in your establishment.

When you have to admit that the best part of the evening out was your company & conversation, the walk to & from the restaurant, the wine before, and yes, the food--  i don't think that says much about the place.  

There's too many other places to try to go back to this one.
author: Diane G.

description: Fantastic service and food. I had to wait a while as it was a rainy Saturday night, but everything was a hit from - the tiny meatballs, salami misto plate to the snapper...desert rocked.
author: craig b.

description: This place rekindled my love of Italian food.  Hugh fan of there desserts and love how they run place.  Out of all the amazing restaurants on Fillmore this one will make you feel like family only after being there once. I live in the neighborhood and never had to call ahead for a small party, but I am sure it would hurt. Great wine selection as well.
author: Kean F.

description: Took my girlfriend and her brother here 2 weeks ago for dinner because she said this is one of her favorite places to eat. The wine that was recommended was perfect. The Bruschetta was really good and the dinner was fantastic. We had a 2nd order of the Zucchini is was that great. Definitely recommend.
author: Ben N.

description:
Food is great, but restaurant is a bit small, loud, and somewhat expensive.
Great Marcona almonds and anchovy-stuffed olives.  Great salmon on cannellini beans.  Staff were friendly.  Great neighborhood too.
author: Sabine W.

description:
This is the perfect, little neighborhood italian restaurant.  
I prefer to sit at the bar and have dinner and just make it casual- this is the place for it.
They always seem to make room for us when arriving at 8pm with everyone else from pac heights.  Ollie will always give us the update on the Giants if we do have to wait.  Then he throws a little something extra about the Dodgers, since I'm a fan.
They know what bottle of wine we like to drink and that starts a perfect evening out.
We usually order a pasta and chicken dish, so we can have a little bit of both. Every time, the pasta is cooked perfectly (I think they may have the best baked pasta).  The chicken g.o.v. is awesome and full of flavor.  This is one place that we totally miss since we have moved to the mission.  But every time we go back for dinner, it just makes it that much better.
author: Valarie A.

description:
What's old  can always be new again.

Used to be you could never get into this place, they didn't take rez's unless you had a large party, people always standing outside on Fillmore every night of the week. What I remembered most about it was the quaint atmosphere and complimentary bruschetta.

Fast forward five years, yes 5 years, some girlfriends and I find ourselves on Fillmore on a Friday night and try to go SPQA or whatever the heck that all letter no name new Italian place is and we hear 2 hour wait....at 6:30? Seriously? 2 hours? You're sure about that? I think your your lying. 

So we started to wander up Fillmore, La Mediterranea was packed , didn't want sushi, maybe Chouquet's and then it came to us....Jackson Fillmore, oh but there sure was to be a wait...we walked up , walked in, seated right away and had as I had remembered good food, great gnocchi and risotto, quaint atmosphere and complimentary bruschetta.  I did forget about the bathroom here, don't go,  it's not nice, you walk thru the kitchen and might just see some things you don't want to.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Solid 3 stars.  Mostly for the rudeness encountered upon entering the establishment.  Yes, I know we had a reservation for 630.  Yes, I know we showed up about 20 min. early.  No, you did not have to be an ass when we asked to be seated away from the door.  And the kicker was when we finally sat us away from the door, he said, under his breath, but loud enough for us to hear, "it's not boston or new york."  as if that's supposed to make us feel bad about asking for a seat away from the freaking door??  truly, how hard is it to walk the extra 5 steps?  truly!

But now on to the food.  My friend and I shared the stuffed artichoke and it was wonderful.  A touch hard to eat because it was freaking hot, but the flavors were all there.  Then I had the pasta with veal sausage and it was wonderful as well.  Their house chianti was a nice pairing with the veal.  

The weird part was at the end when the table next to us was getting ready to leave and the mom felt compelled to tell my friend and I that we were small eaters.  WTF!  Did I comment on the fact that you ate just about everything on the menu?  NO!  I kept my comments to myself.  What on earth could have been the purpose of telling us that.  No idea and don't really care.
author: Alison N.

description:
a little disappointed. 

the service in this place is excellent, however i was underwhelmed by the food. 

my friend ordered the zucchini salad. this is AMAZING. if i ever did go back, i would definitely get this....  my salad was so-so. 

my friend ordered the seafood stew and asked if it was spicy. they told her that it was not generally spicy but that they could "spice it up". i don't like spicy food so that sounded pretty scary to me... i ordered mushroom gnocchi. 

i am not sure why the food was just okay. i am italian and i was very hungry that day so normally i would have eaten almost all of it. the flavors were just not good. they were quite odd... 

my friend's stew was so spicy that she could not eat it. they tired to doctor it up but it was just too much for her. 

i will say that the service was very good and if you order the right thing, i am sure it is a very good place. 

if you plan on going, order the zucchini salad and don't ask them to make anything spicy for you : D hope this helps.
author: Partyhat X.

description: Took my in-laws there and they absolutely loved it. Always give great service and made my favorite risotto even though it wasn't on the menu. This is my daughters favorite restaurant in the city and asks to go every time we head through the tunnel!
author: Chip K.

description: Took my wife and family for a Pre- mothers day dinner. The food was very tasty the only reason my review wasn't higher because the portions were a bit small, but that may be more my issue than theirs. I would recommend this place, give it a try.
author: Marc W.

description:
Unprententious comfort food - people waiting outside in the breezy evening for a seat? Never a bad sign. We were smart enough to call a couple hours ahead to make an 8pm reservation on a Sat evening. Always a smart move, folks! 

It's right in the Fillmore/Jackson area as its namesake explains and a place like this make me very jealous that I don't live in a such a great areas as Pac Heights/Fillmore. Back in my hometown, you wouldn't find authentic comfort food around the corner like this, you'll find instead - families hangin' outside of the Olive Garden by Southland Mall in Hayward dying to get the all you can eat Soup'n'Salad or the Tour of Italy a la fettuccine alfredo, chicken parm and lasagna. 

Lucky for me, my friend's days are numbered in the city so we went to some of her fav hood joints - Fillmore Jackson being one of them. This place is cozy, you just might sit on your neighbors nap, but this place is bustling with locals, couples, families, post-sporting event fans, etc. 

Can't complain about the complimentary bruschetta, or the delish fig first course. Saffron risotto could've definitely used a bit more salt and my linguine di mare was alright too. The sausage and chicken dish though was definitely the best - definitely hearty portion for the boys. 

Best of all the dessert - get the zabaglione - uhhhh yum. I would've lucked the wine glass it was served in. It's the first time I've ever had it and I fell in love - chocolate cake was just as yum. 

What I like most about this place is you don't have to dress up and try desperately to keep your elbows off the table - this place let's you be you, and let's them serve up some comfort cooking that makes you take a short stroll home, change into your jammies and pass out with a smile on your face.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Great neighborhood Italian restaurant in Pacific Heights on, um, well, the corner of Jackson and Fillmore. 

I haven't eaten here in years but on a whim we decided to pop in for dinner tonight. Great choice! The service was fast and attentive, the small but crowded interior created a warm neighborhood feel and the menu was full of inventive takes on southern Italian fare.

We started with the gratis bruscheta (I wish they would put this on the menu, I would have ordered more) and a couple glasses of barbera. Both were excellent.  Next was the prosciutto stuffed artichoke appetizer. Heaven!  I had the gnocchi and Jason had the mushroom ravioli and each dish was flavorful and satisfying. 

Only one negative: Having to schlep through the kitchen to the small and grody bathroom.  Yuck!!

The final touch to a great meal was the lightweight check - only $80 for the two of us which included 4 glasses of wine.  Great casual date or girls night out spot!
author: Megan L.

description:
There's always another place to try on Fillmore Street, don't ya think?  The other night, my boyfriend and some friends met at Jackson Fillmore for dinner and for some catching up.

We had reservations, so we were thankfully seated right away. It looks like they can get pretty full, pretty quick (a quaint place, if you will).  

The menu had a lot of fantastic pasta and meaty options.  I read someone's rave about the pork chops on Yelp!  Even though the waiter tried to nod me away from trying them, I went for it anyway.  They were delicious!

The pork chops were flavored up and juicy.  There were some fried potato skins that were VERY tasty (i'm a sucker for fried potatoes).  It felt like a little bit of Kentucky cooking, which is all right with this country boy.

The prices were maybe a tad bit high, but probably in line with the neighborhood.  I think the pork chops and potatoes ran $18.50.

Afterwards, you can take a walk by Danielle Steele's and other lovely Pacific Heights homes just to the east.
author: Jamie W.

description:
We walked in, noticed one table of four open, while we are a table of two, they wanted us to wait a few for a spot at the bar. I said table for two please. He looks around, overseeing the the only table open and says the bar will be ready in a few... Huh?!?! We prefer a table. He doesn't respond, but luckily the own was not too far away and sat us at the table. It was very much appreciated, but I didn't like the hesitation. As I understand we live in a business world and we are all in it to make as much as we can out of it. But there are just times when it is petty to keep the only table open for the right amount of people especially when you are in your neighborhood and a regular. Obviously the owner knows it, but it needs to be relayed to the wait staff.

The food is absolutely delicious. Their service after we were seated was decent, and as always I cant go wrong with good company.

I'll come back here for comfort food and a good glass of wine. 

Cheers!
author: Dee C.

description: Quality pastas but a little flavorless to be honest.  Wait times can be brutal all nights of the week.  The service is a bit abrupt once you're seated.
author: David L.

description:
We went here on a whim while strolling around Fillmore looking for a dinner spot.  It started off strange and stayed that way.  The host was so rude to us, didn't even look us in the eye and when he came by to take our drink orders, was extremely rude & aloof.  I wanted to get up and leave at that point.

The same thing happened as another reviewer mentioned - the waiter came over about 3 times in 90 seconds to take our order and were very strange about our requests (which were meager.)

The bruscetta was good but based on the inflated prices of everything else (a $9 mayonaisse soaked salad and $17 gnocci and tomato sauce) you'd do better to go somewhere else and pay for it .  The pasta was pretty good, surprisingly, but not worth eveyrthing else.

Also they were playing Linkin Park and hard pop/rock music.  It was so weird and disruptive.

This plays sucks - do not go there, seriously.
author: Reggie G.

description:
It's good, not great. No beer on tap. I was quite disappointed in the food experience. The bruchetta was the best part of the entire meal. Tortellini too salty. Ravioli okay. I was expecting more from the food and atmosphere. Service, okay.

If you want something better overall, yet still Italian - go to Nob Hill Cafe instead. You will not be disappointed with their food!
author: Judy L.

description:
So I hadn't been here since the re-do and didn't quite know what to expect, but things were looking bright from the start as they now accept rezzies on OpenTable. Food is still delicious - complimentary bruschetta is still yummy and garlicky - but they did, in fact, change the menu. Everything on it still looked delicious, although my favorite dish was gone - the bombolotti with tomato and veal ragu and marscapone. Bummer. 

I had spaghetti a'la amatricana which was quite good and the portions are just right. Decently priced bottle of wine for three of us. All in all - good, no frills, consistent, tasty affordable italian meal.
author: Kate S.

description:
Quality has gone way done

Portions are smaller now 

Customer service poor except for the nice tall man that greets you hello and goodbye
author: Cynthia C.

description:
The food was excellent but the service was lacking. All the workers seemed tortured to be working there, and they looked bothered to have to take food orders.  God forbid you ask for food in a restaurant.

The zucchini carpaccio is yummy and the pesto raviolis are divine.  But even if their food is good, I don't think I will ever go back.
author: Vanessa A.

description:
Places like Jackson Fillmore make a neighborhood unique.  And for that I grant it 4 stars.  I'm so over the lame lets-milk-it-for-all-its-worth franchises.  This place is cozy.  The staff is friendly.  The dishes are authentic.  And that is why it gets packed many nights of the week.  

So people with eye-tearing b.o., halitosis, and such - ya mind waiting outside till your table is ready?  Or  just call ahead, since I heard the host saying many times, parties of 3+ can make reservations.

Get this... the prior business of Jackson Fillmore was a sushi restaurant,  over 20 years ago.  Yet it still has the sushi bar case at its bar.  Kind of quirky and cute.

The complimentary bruschetta was a nice welcome gesture.  Arugula salad wasn't anything special but a nice size portion.  The butternut squash ravioli was decent, only because it was diced butternut squash sauteed with the cheese ravioli rather than being tucked inside the pasta.  The sausage from the chicken dish had a nice spicy kick to it.  And I'll be honest, I tried to change my order TWO minutes after I had placed it but the cooks had already grilled up the sausages... and this was after the seafood pasta was 89ed.
author: A W.

description:
Had a small birthday dinner at Jackson Fillmore last night and it was superb.  Just before I left, I jumped on yelp to see what I might want to order and was excited to meet the "mean host" as I have no problem calling people out for poor service...fortunately/unfortunately, the host and owner were both there and they were incredibly nice and accommodating to us as we waited an additional 45 minutes for a friend to show up.

The menu changes daily, except the bruschetta which was delicious.  We had prosecco while we waited which was great, except when we ordered seconds they just refilled our same glass...I'm a bit of a wine snob and would rather they provide me a new glass for a new bottle.

Overall, great food and service and ambiance.
author: David H.

description:
I have loved Jackson Fillmore for four years.  I briefly lived near it for a summer and was entranced by the coziness and the tastiness.  I know the service is sometimes brusque, but I think the food is worth it.  

Case in point, I was up in SF visiting last weekend.  On Sunday night, we needed a gentle and soothing meal while nursing a wicked hangover.  We show up and decide to nurse the hangover with what else but PROSECCO.  A lovely bottle for I believe $20 soon appears.  

Salads are delicious, but pretty standard - the highlights are three - the bruschetta, the pasta and the dessert.  I love the bruschetta.  It is the most delicious garlicy, oily, tomatoey goodness ever.  And, following it, the amatriciana pasta.  SO GOOD!  The most perfect al dente pasta, gently dressed in sweet tomatoes, pancetta and fresh herbs.

Oh, so you think I stopped there?  I kept going!  The affogato (I hope I spelled it right).  It is the most delicious mix of cold and creamy vanilla gelato with a shot of hot espresso!  The most delicious and tasty melted ice cream concoction ever.  Good thing this is up on Jackson so I could just roll back to the hotel
author: Jocelyn W.

description: Amazing neighborhood joint. The restaurant is pretty small, but the ambiance is great. The menu specials constantly change so I suggest trying what is featured! Everything from the gnocchi to the burrata to the complimentary bruschetta is absolutely divine. And if the wait is too long, you can always eat at the bar.
author: Judy K.

description:
This little neighborhood spot was surprisingly delicious. Having read the previous yelp reviews, it was a toss up however my girlfriend and I had a great experience. With no reservation, we got in on a Sat night at 8pm.  The guy at the front must have been the owner and was ultimately friendly.  

From the start, the Bruschetta was delicious and I ordered the rigatoni with veal and mushrooms which was delicious. The rigatoni was cooked perfectly and the marscapone was a nice sweet addition. Naturally, i put red pepper flakes on the meal  but i do that with every meal. I just enjoy spicy food.

My girlfriend got the Zuppa di Pesce which was delicious. the broth did not need any spice. The seafood in the dish was perfect.  

I recommend this as a great place to go for a casual meal. It is inexpensive also which is also a plus.
author: Jared K.

description: I must admit I don't understand the naysayers about this fine local restaurant.  It isn't fancy, and parking isn't easy (still waiting for a neighborhood restaurant in SF where it is), but the food is way above typical neighborhood Italian-oriented restaurants, certainly better than any of the crap that now passes for Italian in North Beach.  The staff is excellent, the wines by the glass are way above average, the prices are modest by San Francisco standards.  No, it isn't Acquerello, but the bill is 25% as much.  I like it.
author: Jonathan H.

description: Delicious authentic Italian food, nice wine selection, fun crowd. The reviewer who gave a negative review because the pasta arrived hot and they don't have pizza... Are you kidding?!? Stick with Domino's and leave that seat for someone else, please.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Delicious food.  Good atmosphere.  The crowd was local and diverse.  We found the staff friendly and inviting.  Pasta portions were moderate, but overall value was not bad.  An outstanding dish was the barely battered calamari.
author: Duke K.

description: Place is not the cheapest, but it is a wonderful local trattoria.  Great service and attitude, feels like you're part of the neighborhood.  Food is great, I recommend sticking to the specials as they are very creative.  Great spot for a nice informal dinner with family and friends.  Price is worth it.
author: Matt C.

description:
The service is somewhat questionable . . . Or rather lacking in the usual Italian hospitability. That said, the pasta entrees are phenomenal. We shared the Insalata Tri Colore. The endive is an excellent touch and adds some crispness to the otherwise soggy greens. The bruschetta they serve with every meal is excellent. I had the Spaghetti Carbonara. It was delicious. The pancetta is prevalent but not overpowering and the sauce is light. The pasta was al dente and cooked to perfection. My friend had the gnocchi. The handmade dumpling reminded me of Italy and the sauce was fresh. The mushrooms in the sauce were a bit much. I give it a 4/5 for the bruschetta and the great pastas and sauces. They get a -1 star for the service and soggy greens. 

I would recommend this to anyone looking for some consistently good Italian food. I have had the meat entrees and would recommend sticking to the pasta.
author: Nicholas C.

description:
Old neighborhood standard.

Service can be a trying but, not disasterous.  Food is solid Italian, haven't been disappointed yet.  Basic Italian dishes from a limited menu, however it covers all bases: chicken, fish, veal, pasta, shrimp.  Portions are just right, not overly generous but, definately getting your money's worth.

When the mod strikes or, not feeling anything in the hood, JF can always be relied on for the casual good eats.
author: Peter Z.

description:
free bruschetta.
dry chicken siciliana.
if i were to come back, i'd get a pasta dish and DESSERT.
author: Shirley L.

description: Great staff, friendly service, excellent food! I appreciated the bruchetta right after ordering. The food was so delicious! I would highly recommend!
author: Jenni M.

description:
Technically I'd probably say 3.5 stars, but I'll round up because I like the spot.

Great neighborhood spot.  The free bruschetta that comes out at the start of the meal is a nice bonus.

Food always is good.  Atmosphere is welcoming. Waitstaff  is attentive.  I recently learned that they are willing to create a few classics, even if they're not on the menu - want eggplant parm...just ask.  

If you're looking for fancy dining, this probably isn't your place.  But if you want a place with decent food, a great value and a comfortable setting, look no further.
author: Todd S.

description:
This place is lit like a prison.  Flourescent lights, really?  Also, when the best part of your meal is the brushcetta, it's not a great sign.  However, this place is affordably priced, fairly authentic, and having a glass of wine while you wait for your table is always a nice touch.  The food is not terribly adventurous, but it's all very good and fresh.  The service is a bit...brusque.

Definitely not a romantic restaurant, but a good date restaurant because it's casual yet with great food.  Everytime I eat here I'm surrounded by people who are clearly on a first or second CL or Match date and making somewhat awkward conversation.  Like the guy last night who was going on and on about his wine buying.  She didn't care, dude.

UPDATE 3/8/07 - went here last night and they've changed the lighting!!!  No longer prison-esque!  Plus a star!
author: Geoff K.

description:
This is a no-nonsense Italian joint and I pat them on the back for it! No muss no fuss. You want an authentic Italian meal that will make you so full you cant even think about rolling down the street for a drink at Harrys, then this is the place to go!

The service is direct and to the point, the restaurant's purpose is to serve you good food and thats it. I appreciate this and kind of put up with their flaky service just to have their incredible meals.

Do yourself a favor and order the gnocci, its cheesy, its rich, its scrumptious. Also the sausage, whoa boy this ones a keeper! I dont usually order sausage but I asked the waiter for his recommendation and was very happy upon taking his advice. The free bruschetta is a nice touch and I always appreciate anything free in SF!
author: Heather S.

description:
Great intimate Italian Trattoria.  Wonderfully fresh and such a low key un uptight eatery in Pac Heights.  

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
You know...I've been here a couple of times, and I really like this place. It's a bit hard to find. Walking up to it, you think it must be deserted, as there's no noise that you can hear from the street. But inside...it's vibrant, full of activity, with almost every table being packed! 

Luckily, in spite of our lack of a reservation, we got seated within a few minutes. We shared a few pasta dishes, all of which were amazing. 

I don't know how to describe it, but it's one of those places where you know you'll always get great food and friendly service.  It is casual enough to be considered a neighborhood trattoria, classy enough for date night, but comfortable enough for a night out with a group of friends.
author: Samir P.

description:
I liked that it was not super expensive.  I had the gnocchi and I thought the actual pasta was pretty good considering there are a lot of places that screw up gnocchi, however, all I could taste was garlic.  I like garlic, but I would have liked some of the other flavors supposedly in the dish.  My friend got the tortellini, my question, where is the tortellini?  All I see is really heavy cream and lots of cheese!  This dish was too much of everything and with each bite you thought it might be your last.  There wasn't even a dent made. To start we had the crab/toast appetizer..NOT GOOD.  This tasted like tuna fish.  It wasn't at all what I was hoping for or expected.  

So, not to be horrible, there were some good things 1) Service was pretty good 2) brushetta to start was a highlight, tasty and 3) the tiramasu was good.  

All in all, wont go back
author: Jaime C.

description:
Sure the pasta sauces on my "bombolotti" and my dinner date's gnocchi were tasty. wow, free bruschetta, that's kind. but you can't call something bombolotti if it comes from a box. Barilla specifically, and since you didn't  make this and although similar to bombolotti, it's not, it's called Rigatoni. period.  (I probably eat Barilla rigatoni at home once per week, sometimes more, hey i'm italian!) 

In this city, with so much Italian food available, no way in heck am I going back to a restaurant that calls itself a trattoria that uses box pasta. sorry. i can eat that at home! or at least just call a spade a spade and i won't be all hatin on you.
author: Sarah G.

description:
It takes a lot for Italian places to impress me, simply because I always feel ripped off when I pay so much for pasta that I could have easily boiled myself at home, but the food here was surprisingly good.

The place was very cozy and intimate, and definitely had that "little neighborhood restaurant" feel to it. It took a while for our party of five to get a table, and we literally had to wait out on the sidewalk because it was so cramped inside.

When we finally got a table, it took forever for the servers to bring us our menus. My friend literally had to get up and go to the bar to steal us a few menus because we were all starving by then. Instead of a basket of fresh bread, there were tiny breadsticks in a container on each table. Initially, my way-too-Asian dining companion thought they were chopsticks, and kinda freaked out when I reached for one and put it in my mouth, LOL.

After we ordered, we each got a HUGE bruschetta placed in front of us, on the house. My piece was especially big and was drenched in delicious EVOO; the size of it made it kind of hard to eat, but it was literally the best and freshest-tasting bruschetta I have ever eaten.

I had the mushroom risotto, and it was very creamy and delicious... but they were a little too liberal with the truffle oil and the first few bites of my dish were wayyy to earthy and mushroomy. The portions were generous, so I had a delicious lunch of leftover risotto the next day.

Even though I really liked the food here, the service was lackluster, and the prices were a little too high for my everyday dining budget. It's a good choice for the yuppies with highly disposable incomes living in the now-kinda-trendy Pacific Heights neighborhood though...
author: Karen L.

description:
Great food.  

The dozen or so times I've been here, I've never had a bad plate.  Always, always, always a tasty meal.

Price keeps you honest, but this is a place for when your with people that deserve a good meal.  Typically, I'll eat with a group here for a late dinner (ie 8pm or 9pm).  

If special friends are in visiting, this is one of the places I would consider bringing them.  You can enjoy great food and spend a good hour or two catching up with good friends in a peaceful environment.
author: M S.

description: I eat out a fair amount, both on business and socially.  This place has decent food, but some of the rudest, most arrogant staff in San Francisco.   The most recent time I went there was at another person's suggestion.  It was a business meeting, and I arrived five minutes before the official opening time.  Despite the drizzle outside, I was told to wait in the street, even though we had a reservation.  When my host arrived, we decided to go elsewhere.  I will not return no matter who invites me.
author: charles h.

description: Far from authentic Italian food.  Ingredients could have been fresher.
author: Mike B.

description: Revisited JF after several years away, and I must say it's as great as ever.  Two dishes alone make it entirely worth a visit: Zucchini Carpaccio, simple and wonderful, with almonds and Pecorino, just delicious!  And the Insalata Primavera, imaginative combination of fresh crisp veggies, a beautiful salad.  Even for a carnivore like myself, these two are total winners.  As others have said, neighborhood feel and superb cuisine -- wonderful.  They've got it down.
author: John P.

description:
Came here with a few friends for a birthday dinner. A few had been previously, and remembered the food being very good. After the meal, they claimed they must have been drunk at the time, because we all left disappointed.

I'll keep this brief, since I don't have anything nice to say:
- The bruschetta was pretty good, but far too oily. 
- My tortellini with prosciutto was warm and unspectacular under a hard blanket of cold cheese. 
- My good friend described his linguini as "wet cardboard".

For the prices, you'll find far better Italian elsewhere.
author: Jory M.

description:
This place is my fav. I hit it up whenever I can and always with my pops (who tends to eat italian as one of his two cuisines).

Let me set you up for success.

Start with the fried mozzarella. Next, order off the menu and go with the Tortellini de la casa (meat filled tortellini with marinara sauce.) Top it off with the cold zabaglione. If this doesn't satisfy you, go back to your hole.
author: Allen X.

description:
This small hole in a wall Italian place serves up some delicious plates.  It's a small resturant that fills up fast, so show up early or try to reserve a spot for dinner.  The waiters are attentive and the dishes come out in a timely manner.

Oh ya, the bruschetta is pretty damn good.
author: David C.

description: I was looking for a casual place to drink some wine  and eat some Italian food with my boyfriend and found this to be the perfect spot.  We ordered the mushroom appetizer which was amazing.  I'm not even a  huge fan of mushrooms but this dish was yummy!  The artichoke was cooked in a way I'd never seen before, covered in parmesan and ham(i think it was ham) and baked until soft, delicious, and melty.  If you like artichokes, try this!  The service was awesome and comfortable.  I felt like the cook/waiter was an old friend of mine although it could have been the 2nd glass of wine.  We left feeling warm, full, and happy.
author: Ambar M.

description:
This is one of those rare neighborhood places that has remained consistent throughout the years.  Coming here reminds me of those large Italian family dinners that my best friend's mom used to invite me to -- a joyous environment with lots of good food and wine.  

We came back on a busy Friday night and while we waited 30 mins for our table, we enjoyed a nice glass of wine, which made the time go by much faster.  The staff was very attentive and came out to check on us (and the other patrons) every 10 mins.  Paying attention to waiting customers always earns bonus points in my book.  

Once we were seated, I ordered the Chicken Siciliana, which was moist and quite flavorful.  The green olives aren't overpowering and are a nice complement to the garlic, capers and white wine.  My only complaint was several of the pieces were all bones.  

My BF had the linguine and shrimp with spicy red sauce -- this is probably the restaurant's best dish and once again it didn't disappoint.  They give you a healthy serving of shrimp, which makes this a wonderful dish to share.

Overall, the service is good, however, if you are sitting at the bar, you need to be a little assertive because sometimes it takes a little longer to get the attention of the one waiter who is responsible for the entire bar area.
author: S Y.

description:
I've been going for years and it doesn't get old. Between the daily specials (grilled salmon on a bed of greens with fried baby artichokes - still dreaming about it!!) , the regular menu and the house policy "special requests will be considered", I always have a hard time choosing. Go with people who will share.

I feel comfortable eating there as a single too. Sitting at the counter is fun, and the wine list has a great selection by the glass.
author: connie j.

description: We went to Jackson/Fillmore for the 1st time last night.  It is easy to miss if you are not looking carefully as it is a modest exterior with minimal signage (my wife walked by it twice).  We made early reservations were seated in a window table that was great.  We all ordered from the nightly specials menu and were very impressed with the food and atmosphere.  It is really a neighborhood place with the hustle and bustle of the popular small Italian restaurant  that it is and you would expect.  The food and service was very good - the prices reasonable - and we will be going back.  Fair warning: the place was packed with people waiting the whole time we were there - make sure to make a reservation!
author: Jerry B.

description:
I always leave Jackson Fillmore happy, full and a little tipsy.  This is one of my favorite casual places to go- good for dinner with friends, family or a date.  

The bruchetta is heaven.  All the apps I've tried are good and their meat pastas are always a solid bet.  This isn't fancy, high concept food but it's damn good.  The wine selection is limited so just order the Montapulciano and be happy with it.  Avoid dessert.  

***Space is recently refreshed - it is cozier with a dark red wall running the length of the room and new tabletop setup. ***
author: Lena J.

description:
*Disclaimer: heavily philosophic review concluded by reference to seminal Kierkegaardian film (Trainspotting)*

Let it be said that San Franciscans are used to, dare we say expect, a somewhat touchy-feely dining experience.  We're a liberal and gregarious city after all, and our restaurants are a manifestation of those values.  Our restaurants are the nexus of Frisco culture and philosophy: egalitarian, friendly, relatively unassuming and approachable.

So if you be pickin up what i be puttin down, you may be gettin privy to the bias we Friscans bring to restaurant service: we like smiles, specials, amuse-bouches and "how is everything?"s.  And Jackson Fillmore Trattoria doesn't deliver those.  Jackson Fillmore Trattorie is the curt, matter-of-fact contrast to the Montessori-esque SF dining experience.  And that's cool w/ me.

Jackson Fillmore Trattoria has outstanding, authentic, fresh and seasonal Italian food.  It has a small, cozy ambiance, and a large bar at which I recommend eating.  With good food as your criterion, you will not be disappointed.

The staff are no-nonsense, and yes we did notice some older, richer looking types getting priority ahead of us.  But that's the game baby!  Trust me, it could be a lot worse (New York City much?)  

So tough it out, turn that frown upside down, and take it from me: this spot is worth the attitude, and if you end up closing up the joint with a few more glasses of wine, the staff do indeed warm up to you.  And that tastes sweeter than any panne cotta in the world.
author: Aaron K.

description:
I thought it was supposed to be a good old fashion 'neighborhood' restaurant.  Very understated exterior, we almost didn't see the neon sign on the glass window. Well, certain restaurant owners think that they are cool this way, no really need to have a good sign, as if they are so good that people will be definitely able to find them no matter what (in this case, Tartine Bakery is the same too). What are they thinking anyway? Snob!

Well, let's talk about the food here. I tried it and I can't complain much about the food, but the service was just so unsatisfying. I almost thought our waiter did not know how to smile, BUT wait until I saw him greeted some 'regulars'. Hey, that's the kind of service I am hoping for, BUT nay...he just reserved his smile for the 'regulars'. IF you are just an occasion eater there, DO NOT expect much, BUT eat your food! (you should be glad that they want to serve you).

Food wise, good enough for me. BUT i won't go back for the service. There are so many restaurants out there, why do I have to deal with the 'no smiling' face. Move on...Check please! Next...
author: kelly n.

description: Great staff, delicious food and a nice neighborhood feel. From my first visit in 2002 to now, this restaurant consistently delivers the goods :-)
author: Dan A.

description: Everything I tasted here was good, from the salmon, to the salads, to the spicy shrimp pasta dish I ordered.  I love that you get free bruschetta (which is delicious).  Its one of the nice touches that pushes this place into four star territory.  The prices on the main courses are very reasonable, but the prices on the starters are a few dollars higher than I would expect.  The atmosphere was cozy and it felt like everyone had walked to this place, which is cool.   We split a bottle of wine with another couple and still managed to spend less than a $100.  Seemed like you needed reservations, particularly on a Saturday night.
author: matt h.

description: This place is an average neighborhood restaurant ... small, friendly and food that has hits and misses.  The staff is definitely very friendly and inviting, helpful with the menu.  The free bruschetta was decent.  I liked the arugula salad a lot but the zucchini carpaccio was a definite miss.  Some of the pasta dishes were good but some tasted like i could have made them (and I can't cook).
author: Craig V.

description: I always have a solid meal at Jackson Fillmore.  It's my favorite Italian restaurant in the city.  Sure, there are many Italian restaurants with bigger reputations but if you just want a solid Italian meal with fresh ingredients, a low key ambiance, and no attitude, then get on down to Jackson Fillmore.  The breaded chicken with heirloom tomatoes is a special choice.
author: Mark G.

description:
I have been to Jackson-Fillmore half a dozen times and I've always thought the food was excellent. The bruschetta that is delivered to your table instead of the run-of-the-mill bread loaf is a great touch and sets the stage to what is always a satisfying meal. 

The downside to this restaurant is the service. The first time I came here I sat at the bar and the service was wonderful. The next three times I came here I brought friends and family, and each time the service was slow and inattentive, however with a group it was not a big deal. 

What WAS annoying was the next time I went it was before 9pm on a Thursday and they said they were closed. The restaurant was 3/4 full and other customers had not been served their entrees yet. Again this was before 9pm and the hours on the window said they were open till 10pm. We left without explanation, feeling completely dejected. 

The most recent time, and the last time, I went to JF was because my mom was in town, I had taken her here before, and this is where she wanted to go. We had to wait for 10 minutes for a table, and when we were seated the server was short and rude and not interested in providing anything close to a decent level of service.
author: Hugh B.

description:
UPDATE: Okay, my boyfriend and I came here late night after a football game and sat at the bar. The bartender helped us select  a great bottle of wine and our food was really really good! I tend to shy away from JF with all of the other great Italian spots in our neighborhood, but I had to give them props for the amazing meal we had.

I really like this place. I live around the corner so have been quite a few times in varying situations from dates to girls night out and have always had a good time. The food isn't amazing, however, and the place heats up like an oven! I go for the cozy ambiance and good service.
author: Shannon C.

description:
Bruschetta, bruschetta, bruschetta, bruschetta, bruschetta, its comped and its like Italian crack - so damn good.   I give this place four stars for the brushet and food, one star for service, specifically the older guy working the door/seating chart. 

He can be a jerk every now and then, case in point.   We showed up one time with a party of five and he sat us with the stipulation that we'd be out in 50 minutes - deal or no deal?  We took the deal.   On the off chance you happen to catch him on a good night you're looking at a four star dinning experience.  

Bruschetta, bruschetta, bruschetta, bruschetta, bruschetta, bruschetta! 

Nuf said.
author: E P.

description:
My favorite little neighborhood Italian nook. Ok, so not the most amazing Italian I have had- but the coziness, free bruschetta, and friendly service keep us coming back. Whether with friends, family or the one I love, the liveliness in this small space always make me feel proud to be a local and know about little gems like this. They greet my bf by his name every time we stroll in and will even put a little table in the middle of the pathway to make some room--- they appreciate their returning patrons for sure. 

I'm a fan of their seasonal salads for a starter (the last one we got had pomegranates in it) and I have never had a pasta dish I do not like. There desserts are hit or miss-- I suggest skipping it and going to grab some frozen yogurt or other treats.
author: Rena Z.

description:
They get one star because the neighborhoodsy feel and the casual decor and because yelp does not allow zero stars..

Service was brusque and entrees took forever to come out. We ordered some cheese and there was no bread, so we asked for bread and instead got bruschetta--which I found out from reading these reviews is complimentary. I guess they forgot to bring it over initially. The waiter at the bar almost purposefully dropped a serious knife on my fiance's lap and barely even apologized. Scary moment.

Food was awful. The cheese we ordered was mt. tam and they microwaved it! WTF? You microwave cheap brie, not a nice piece of mt. tam. We had the meatballs which were dry and flavorless. The carbanora sauce on the pasta tasted like it came from a packet of cream of mushroom soup. The biscotti and vin santo we had for dessert were awfully stale and the vin santo was watered down.

I've been wanting to try this place for a while so I am glad I finally did and now I can cross it off my list and never have to go back there again!
author: Monster R.

description: The complimentary bruscetta to start is probably the best bruscetta I've ever had! I've tried the pastas and every one of them is delicious (although tortellini stands out). The seafood entrees are amazing as well. And the wine selection was fairly good (nothing too exciting there in my opinion...) Just remember that you'll probably end up waiting any day of the week during prime dinner hours. The decor inside is very modest as well. Regardless, you won't be disappointed!
author: Chihee K.

description:
there is something to be said for an establishment that has people older than the fixtures still dining at their local nook. Great little spot ... better if you try it during the week when it is not so crowded... 

For sure think it is one of the best spots in SF for old school Italian... even if it is or is not owned by that old family from Sicily

giving Franchino in North Beach a run for his money!
author: Drew B.

description: I had dinner with three friends at Jackson Fillmore Trattoria last night.  One of my friends claims it's the best Italian food she's had in California; I, on the other hand, thought that my linguine with shrimp and prawns was good but not exceptional (comparable to Pazzia and Aperto but not as good as Delfina or my East Bay favorites).  There was only one vegetarian pasta on the menu, but when asked, the waiter said that a few of the others could be made vegetarian.  The dessert special was phenomenal, though - a creation akin to a large truffle filled with chocolate ganache and sour cherries, served with dulce de leche.
author: Grace W.

description:
I really like the food and enjoy the cozy space, only one small complaint...please change the music.  Feel like I'm listening to endless KKSF, sick sick sick of saxaphone music.  What's wrong with having some Dean Martin, Frank Sinatra, or Italian opera?  

The food is good and the prices fair, wine list could use some work, a bit pricey for the offerings.  But as neighborhood restaurants go, it's OK.
author: Steve H.

description: Bruschetta is amazing & comes with every meal! Tortellini & goat chees andvtomatoe salad were also wonderful! Will definitely visit on my next trip to San Francisco! Restaurant is small so make a reservation & be prepared to be close to another party.
author: Allyn M.

description: Yummy!  Haven't been here in awhile.  Refreshing to know that it's still packed, service is still friendly, and the food is still delicious.  We waited about 15 mins around 8pm on a Saturday evening, not bad.  We sat at the counter which is where I typically sit.  We shared the Insalata Romana (Arugala tossed with pecorino cheese, julienne salami, in a fresh tomato balsamic vinaigrette. The Ultimate Arugala Salad) - tasty & light.  The Spaghetti alla Carbonera (Spaghetti with pancetta, onion, garlic, black pepper, and chili flakes, with a touch of cream, parmigiana, and an egg yolk) - this was amazing!  I highly recommend.  It's heavy but well worth the splurge.  We balanced the meal off with the Zuppetta di Pesce (Fish and shellfish stew in a light herb tomato sauce) - great flavor with a kick.  I think it would be fab if this was served w/ 2 slices of garlic bread.  Prices are pretty reasonable but glad to know there's a good Italian restaurant in the hood.
author: Meredith K.

description: I live around the corner and I love Italian food.  This place just doesn't do it for me.  Everything seems too rich and heavy handed.  I'm also not willing to wait outside for a table.  Simply not.  Ever.  Yet lots of lovely looking people do.  Service is not too good inside, either. The place has got a certain simpleness, with the counter and the bright lights, that somehow works.
author: Barbara M.

description:
Jackson Fillmore is literally around the corner from my apartment, so I really wanted this place to be awesome. 

I know exactly which guy the "rude server/host" comments refer to.  I think honestly his attitude is part of the whole European vibe of the place--more on this in a second. 

With respect to the food, I think its good but not great. The sauces always seem a bit heavy to me, and the portions are huge. The pasta doesn't seem that fresh either. This makes the host's attitude not that worth it. If the food were amazing and really "authentic" I would be willing to put up with it, but its not. So I can't really stomach the rudeness.

I still swing by every once in a while given the convenience of the place and the decency of the food, but would not recommend that anyone go out of their way to eat there especially given how crowded and loud it is.
author: Matthew F.

description: From the outside this place looks nondescript and maybe even a little run down but inside is a bustling trattoria.  It was a little pricey but the food was divine.  The free bruscetta was a nice touch.  We started with a sampler appetizer that was a daily special, I don't recall the name but it was a nice start for a group of six to share.  I ordered the gambas ala catalana (shrimp with chorizo and chickpeas) and it was very rich and quite delicious.  My fiance ordered an asparagus pasta in white sauce (another daily special) which was quite good but rather light for a dinner meal.  The wine list was excellent as was the service.
author: Nikki R.

description: OMG! We there for my friend's birthday and we had a wonderful time.  The food was great, the atmosphere wonderful and the service impeccable.
author: Alejandra V.

description:
Great Local Italian.  Great wine.  Great Staff.  Zucchini carpaccio is a must.  I order the montepulciano just so I can say "Montepulciano". 
If you live in the neighborhood, you'll know.  Otherwse: quit crowd'n my local joint!!
author: Doug F.

description:
It's true, the bruschetta is Italian crack - pure bliss in your mouth.  It is also true the older guy who seats you/waits on you can be a bit moody sometime (or most of the time) but it is all part of the Italian atmosphere...you never get superb service in Italy.  They have new rules now regarding reservations - you can leave a message and book a table for 3 or more people which is great news.  Parties of 1 or 2 will have to take a chance but I have never waited more than 15mins for a seat.

Whatever you do, make sure you save room at the end of the meal for either choice of the Zabigone (cold with fruit or the traditional hot)...it is almost better than the bruschetta...
author: Hannah L.

description: Hint to Jackson Fillmore....if you cannot accommodate a reservation at the reserved time be upfront about how long the wait will be otherwise you look like liars without a lot of respect for your patrons.
author: Caitlin O.

description: Favorite restaurant - from a normal night when we want to be a little indulgent to the go-to restaurant for my friends' engagement night. Food is always delish, servers are wonderful, and the feel of being so taken care of in our own backyard is truly special.
author: D S.

description: Stopped into this small little neighborhood Italian spot on a Sunday evening.    Overall impression was excellent.   The seating is limited and the decor is a little bleak.   That just adds to the neighborhood feel of the place.   Ordered the bombolotti pasta with a spicy Italian sausage and veal sauce.   It was delicious.   The wine list was extensive and the complimentary bruschetta was good.   Everyone enjoyed their dishes and the service was great.   I haven't experienced alot of SF Italian spots, but this rates as one of the best places I've eaten in SF to date.   Only negative is that prices are a bit steep considering the decor and neighborhood feel to the place.   Entrees are in the $17-19 range with wine ranging from $30 and up.
author: Mike B.

description:
OK, live in the hood but had to voice my opinion given the schizophrenic reviews. I think all of the really negative reviews had to do with the service, and in particular one male host.  I recognized him immediately but here is my take -- don't think he is rude or obnoxious.  Rather, more like efficient in the European sense.  He wasn't particulary friendly but wasn't rude or obnoxious.   There was no smile when he greeted us, but when asked about wine, he offered to pour us a taste of one of the reds.  

Now about the food - nothing to rave about , but pretty solid.  Perfect neighborhood place to go when you don't want to make a big production of the evening and just want a decent meal.  Dressing on the salads was a bit think and "Mayonaise-ey" but I thought it worked, at least with the Arugula salad.  My entree of Liguini with scallops was fine, and my dining partner had the chicken, also pretty good.  Split the cold zabaglione (sp?) for dessert, which again was good, but not like OMG. 

Bottom line, a fine neighborhood Italian that I'll defnitely return to when I feel like staying in the hood for a low-key dinner.
author: Lee Y.

description: The beginning and the end were deelish, the entrees a little let down.  We started with the bruschetta - excellent, probably the best I've had in the city.  We had 3 entrees - rissoto with seafood, linguini and clams, spaghetti alla carbonara.  All 3 were ok, but nothing special.  The rissoto was a bit runny, needed a bit more flavor.  both pastas were a bit better, but nothing to run back and get.  The zabaglione was freshly made, with a nice twist of amerreto and cookies - and was out of this world good.
author: Paul C.

description:
After hearing about Jackson Fillmore (JF) for 6 years, I finally went to JF this weekend. I wasn't disappointed!

This is definitely a no-nonsense place. If you try to customize a dish, you will be told flat out if they won't accommodate you. But it's in the spirit of serving the food as it is intended to serve and you have to appreciate the directness!

We started with a few salads and the mushroom appetizer. It's good if you really like sausage. The gnocchi was DELICIOUS and worth every creamy cheesy calorie. The chicken POV is simple but great - just don't wear white if you order it. I left JF with balsamic vinegar splashed all over me! Dinner is served a-la-carte and I suggest ordering several and sharing if going with a group. Dessert is also good.

The restaurant is not big and reservations are a must. This is a great neighborhood spot with authentic Italian food.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
My BFF took her 92 year old grandmother for a day of shopping and dining in the city. They had a splendid time UNTIL COMING HERE. I've eaten here before and she has been a regular until saying she experienced, "the worst customer service ever of my life." 
She hoped to have Jackson Fillmore's lovely desserts before taking her grandmother back home to Vacaville after a full and beautiful day. 
This is what happened. The waiter would not seat them at a table and offered them to sit at the bar. Grannie on a bar stool at 92????? She asked again and said, my grandma is ninety-two with a walker she can't sit on a bar stool. Waiter's reply, "Well then we can't serve you if you are not having dinner." HELLO, WAITER!!!! Next time your granny visits, would you ask her to sit on a high bar stool. God help her not to break a hip because of your thoughtlessness. 
I too have experienced rather cold service here as well, where my smile gets a cold grimace in return. That's why I haven't gone back in  awhile. My friend and her grandmother deserved a seat like everyone else, based on the fact her grandmother would be considered handicapped. I hope Jackson Fillmore you will make every effort to seat ALL your guests and comp the next dessert and coffee for my friend and her grandmother. You ruined their day. Hope you're happy.

My question now is, Is bad service now the norm or the exception?  Because lately, I've thrown out a lot of bad reviews and guess what??
ALL OF YOU DESERVED IT!
author: J A.

description:
I went here a few months ago, and I'm still thinking about the amazing smelling pork chops that I decided not to order that night, in favor of their carbonara pasta.  I could only lust after a plate of it meant for another customer, while it lingered at the pick-up counter, which Berna and I were seated next to, at the tail-end of the cramped bar. 
The carbonara was pretty good (still not what Basta Pasta's used to be like *tear*), and I loved their complimentary bruschetta - thick sliced, and topped with wonderfully garlic-y tomatoes & herbs. 
Why haven't I been back?  Cuz I have better things to do than be ignored by my server for most of my meal. 
I feel like this is one of those small businesses that gets so packed every night - they don't really care to please anymore.  Our meal took over 2hrs, and seated RIGHT next to the kitchen, we actually saw when our entree ticket was finally put in - long after our shared salad had been served and devoured.  
If someone else wants to take the extra effort to make ressies and 
go here, I'll be willing to join up, but I've got other pork chops in this city to try.
author: CINDY K.

description: I really love this place and it's my favorite neighborhood Italian spot. It might be a little crowded and often even a little warm inside, but the food is quite good, the prices are reasonable, and the people are very nice and provide excellent service. Try the tortellini if you dare - it's super rich but holy cow it's good. Pay attention to the specials as well as the chef often puts together some interesting but tasty concoctions. If you like neighborhood places, this is for you.
author: Amber P.

description:
Yum!  I can't believe this place is so close to me and I hadn't been yet.  I will definitely be adding it in to the regular rotation.  I went recently and shared a spring salad with friends - absolutely delicious.  I felt like I was eating the bounty of spring, so fresh!  I then had the Gambas ala Catalana.  It was really good.  It had a lot of flavor, but wasn't spicy.  The chorizo was in small pieces so you got the flavor, but the meal didn't feel heavy.  When I go back, I will be torn between wanting to try something new and wanting those shrimp again!
The only downside was the small space.  There were three of us at a table for two and I was basically sitting in the walkway.  But, I do love the neighborhood feel and I can definitely look past the cramped quarters.
author: Samantha R.

description: Great service, very knowledgeable. The place was packed, but we were seated pretty quickly. While we waited the owner chatted us up and made us feel at home.  Awesome Italian food. The closest I can get to my grandpa's kitchen in SF.  I will be a regular.
author: K K.

description:
chill neighborhood eat.

after a long hard day at work and staring at my fridge with butter and beer, it was a no brainer to eat at the bar at this joint.

the staff is down to earth and friendly.  the place is quite casual, small and cozy.  the wait was but 15 mins for walk ins on a thursday night.

i had a vanilla italian soda with my bombolotti and arugula salad.  my friend had the tuna app and tortellini which was quite filling and rich.  

for dessert, i ordered the zabaglione and found the flavor a little too sharp.  instead, go for the affrogato.  much tastier and a better way to end a reasonable and solid meal.
author: Anh V.

description: Came here with my best friend and a few other girls for game planning for her wedding. The food wasn't very memorable but we had good wine plus the waiter was funny! He came over and made jokes and everything (he might have been the owner). Next time I'll go back and give the food another try. I might have been a bit distracted by the wedding planning =P
author: Tiff W.

description: My sister's fat bf said good things about this place.  I am never listening to him ever again.  He is only in charge or finding food in Hong Kong or Chinatown.  Thats it.  The best part of the meal was the bruschetta.  Other than this dish everything else was just ok.  I don't even remember what I ate.  I just remembered paying $160 for 5 people.  WOOT!  After we ate here half of the people were still hungry.  Its sad because I only live 2 blocks from here.  Now I have to walk down the hill into the Marina to Pane E Vino for Italian food.  Fat people don't like to walk.  Let alone walking up and down 3 big hills.  LAME!
author: Fatty A.

description:
I came here Saturday night w/ a group of 7 for a carbo load before the marathon on Sunday.  We got carbs.  We also got poor service. 

Our menus were dropped off and without even getting a chance to look them over, the waiter (I think he may have been an owner or manager, as he was the only one in plainclothes and seemed to be running the show)  asked us if we knew what we wanted.  Of course we didn't so we asked for a few more minutes to decide.  Approx 90 seconds had gone by before he came back and asked again.  Repeat two more times.  When asked if someone could make a simple switch from steak to chicken on their pasta, he was extremely adamant about NOT honoring the request.  I would have understood had there not been chicken on the menu, but quite a few dishes had chicken and it should have been a simple requst.  I ordered the Insalata Verdure and what it really was was a side-salad-sized bunch of chopped romaine and a few zucchini and cauliflower slices.  Not exactly $9 worth in my opinion.  It also came SLATHERED in a mayo based dressing, to the point where I thought I was actually just eating spoonfuls of mayo.  Bleck.  

Once the waiter had dropped off our food, he was nowhere to be found.  I had to wait for 5 minutes before I got a fork or before he even walked in our direction.  He seemed genuinely disinterested and possibly annoyed at our group.  We weren't even drinking (!!!).  I'd give the place one star but the free bruschetta barely brought it up to a two-star rating.

All in all, Jackson Fillmore Trattoria left a bad taste in my mouth (literally and figuratively) and I don't anticipate returning when there are plenty of other Italian joints in the city.
author: Kathleen B.

description: You know... I'm not really that impressed. I was really willing to give this joint the benefit of the doubt but after a few solid tries, I've landed on my final answer....If it wasn't 13 paces from my front door, I wouldn't bother. Therefore, if it's not 13 paces from YOUR front door, don't.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I've seriously walked by this place so many times thinking it's a brunch place and saying to myself "hm, it's a saturday afternoon... why isn't this place open?" It was only recently that I realized that it is in no way, shape or form a brunch diner but, in fact, an italian trattoria.  Go figure.

So I came last night before a fillmore show w/ Liz U. and I realized that there is a huge neon sign in the front window that reads "Trattoria".  Okay. Moving on.  We had a reservation so we didn't need to wait long, but there were two other parties of two so they divided a six top into three two tops.  It kinda felt like we were in a cafeteria since everyone was so close together and talking really loud, but the food - well, this was not cafeteria food.

We started out with a bottle of wine and were each brought a huge chunk of crispy bruschetta.  Yelpers don't lie... this is some good sh*%!!  They obviously either make their own or use a really high quality olive oil.  My dining companion even had the balls to ask for another slice and the bus boy gladly brought it over.  For our entrees, she got a chicken dish and I got the gnocchi with tomatoes and swiss chard.  Good god, it was delicious.  The gnocchi were melt-in-your-mouth divine droplets of heaven.  It is a pretty generous portion so I thought I wouldn't be able to move after eating the whole dish, but I surprisingly had room for dessert! :)  Liz got the chocolate torta and I got the infamous tiramisu.  The chocolate torta was so-so I thought, but OMG the tiramisu was seriously the best I've had since I was in Italy.  Liz even admitted that she liked it, and she usually doesn't eat the stuff!! They really know what they're doing here.  Service was good, it seems like it would be fun to eat at the bar (I guess if you're a solo or 2 ppl walk-in they like to sit you there).  I'd definitely come back.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Complimentary Bruschetta! It was quite good, the tomatoes were fresh and seasoned just right, and the bread was toasted to perfection. What a great way to start a meal.

I ordered the portabello mushroom and asparagus salad. It was very aromatic due to the fresh basil and roasted thyme. For my entree I chose the thick tube pasta with veal sausage in a light cream tomato sauce.  It was spicier than I had anticipated, but still very tasty.

Overall, a nice little neighborhood spot.  It definitely got busier as the night went on. I asked for a diet Coke and was offered Italian Flavored Sodas.  How American of me to forget that I was eating at an Italian Trattoria.  Oops.
author: Caryn L.

description: I've eaten here over a dozen times; mostly because it's a stones throw away from where I live.  It is the definition of a neighborhood eatery.  The food is great, particularly the veal chop but any of the pastas are wonderfull as well.  Be forewarned because it get packs early and can get kind of elbow-to-elbow at the tables.  Its not a scene and it ain't the best decor inside either, but if you are looking for a place that packs it in and serves great Italian food at a reasonable price...you won't be dissapointed.
author: Young P.

description: Longtime neighborhood standby for Italian food.  Complimentary bruschetta to start the meal is always nice.  The Tortellini Al Forno is really good - save it for a cold or rainy day as it's on the hearty side (meat filled + proscuitto + cream sauce + melted mozzarella & parmesan cheese).  The gnocchi is just okay.  The Veal Chop (Lombatta Di Vitello) is huge and nicely broiled.  Nice alternative to heading over to North Beach when you have a craving for Italian.
author: Scott R.

description: Great food- the zabaglione freddo was wonderful. I love the fact that everyone gets free bruschetta- makes me feel like VIP even when I'm not.  The wine did taste like Carlo Rossi though.
author: Noelle Q.

description: What could be better, we called from our apartment and in five minutes they put together a table for seven.  Overall the evening was wonderful, four star food and five star company.  The restaurant always starts with their brochette which is full of garlic and bound to give you bad breadth for the rest of the night  but regardless, it is oh so good.  We then had the calamari to start which was tasty but a little overdone. I moved on to the "contadino misto" dish which was incredible.  Lots of garlic (again, more bad breadth), potatoes, sausage and chicken.  My meal was five stars but my sister's meal and my mom's meal was  nothing to write home about.  All and all a great experience and I will happily return soon.
author: Amanda L.

description: Above-average trattoria serving some tasty bruschettas, salads, and main courses.  Both the red snapper and the chicken cutlet dishes were spot on.
author: Tim G.

description: After taking a few year hiatus from Jackson Fillmore, I went back for the first time last Friday.  I was pleased to find they now take reservations for parties of 2 and introduced my Italian born friend to their pasta.  He is verrrry picky.  He approved of all 4 courses.  I have been drooling thinking about their prosciutto, Parmesan and bread crumb topped artichoke.  I can't wait to go back and have it again soon.
author: Jessica V.

description: Nice food, nice service. I have been there a few times as I used to live around the corner. It is a small place so the menu changes a bit and sometimes I the food is fabulous- sometimes just okay. The bruschetta is very well done and the service is friendly- although because they are small and want to turn tables, there is a chance you may feel a little rushed.
author: Sara W.

description: I love the bruschetta here! And the pasta here is super too! When I used to live in Pacific Heights I went here all the time. Although the service can sometimes be spotty, their pastas are consistently good and their bruschetta's are amazing! You get one free everytime you come but I usually end up ordering more! Can't wait to go there again - a great neighborhood place and a solid, no frills, Italian pasta restaurant overall!
author: Chris L.

description: I've been to this place only two times despite the fact that I live only a block away. Perhaps that says something, or perhaps it's just the fact that I don't really enjoy eating Italian at restaurants (I blame my Italian grandmother for this one). In any case, Jackson Fillmore is ok, but I like the small neighborhood trattoria atmosphere more than the food itself. That being said, if you're in the mood for Italian, check it out and skip the tourist traps lining Columbus.
author: Chris B.

description: Was looking for a dinner place post Sundance movie and stumbled upon Jackson, as theyhad a reservation available on OpenTable.  We were happily surprised by the place.  The service was friendly and efficient.  The waiter accidentally knocked over my water glass at the end of the meal -- and more than made up for it by bringing us a free slice of the chocolate dessert.  Oh my, this was the best dessert I have had in a while...it was amazing!  We shared the Sugo pasta, Gnocchi, and Pollo Siciliana -- all of which were really tasty.  Highly recommended for a nice, authentic, italian dinner out,
author: Kimberly G.

description: This restaurant showed me that if you don't succeed first time, try again.  I wasn't so impressed the last time I came here. but last night was a great experience.  The bruschetta was delicious, and not some piddly little piece of bread but a great big piece with lots of fruity olive oil contrasting nicely with the garlic and tomato.  Great way to start a meal.  Next was the penne arriabiata- not on the menu, but the waiter graciously brought it on our request.   The desserts- I can't decide which I liked better, the sliky chocolate fantasy or the cold zabligione with the crunch of amaretti cookies.    I'll definitely come back!
author: Smruti S.

description:
forget north beach. if you want to get your carb on with some good italian food head to jackson fillmore. it's small and crowded but authentic.  it will never be as good as my mom's but....it will do until my next trip back home.  supercasual atmosphere...like get to know your neighbor, which could be kind of fun.

celebrities you MIGHT see here: extras from the sopranos
author: Angela N.

description: This is definitely one of the better Italian restaurants in the city.  Everything I've tried here has been delicious... not your standard Italian pasta dishes.  The complimentary bruschetta is definitely the best bruschetta I've ever had... not just because it's free.  I also like that its family run... friendly service, no pretense.  I'd upgrade my rating if they added more veggie options.  :-)
author: seema s.

description: I sat at the bar and had a descent carbonaro. I finished it and had ice cream which was very good, pistachio chocolate (Gelato Classico Italian I asked). I would come here again, it's a good place to eat by yourself at the bar. On the help side they seemed fine just not polished. If I had to take a guess every night is a struggle finished off with wine laughs and hugs between the staff. You could get a much better dish for about the same price at SPQR but the atmosphere isn't the same, it's better here. The BTG wine selection was limited but I tried two and they were good, albiet a bit pricey (9 per glass). Hell it's just good to see people smile while they work.
author: Stephen S.

description:
If you are looking for an old school San Francisco restaurant, with great Italian food, a diverse wine list, and a friendly owner, spend your Saturday night here.  My girlfriend and I showed up for a 7:30 reservation fifteen minutes early and were greeted by one of the owners/managers, who offered us a glass of wine (which we paid for) while we waited.  We were seated on time at a small table that was packed between other patrons, but it was not too loud and the tight seating added to the ambiance. Very rare to feel this in a city restaurant.  We started with the Carpaccio di Zucchini which comes with toasted almonds and pecorino. One of the best appetizers I have had..the perfect amount of sauce and cheese, almonds were a nice touch as well. I had the Tortellini al Forno for my main meal. While a bit heavy on the cheese, the meat inside was very good as was the prosciutto and cream sauce. My GF had the Pollo alla Noci, and said it was a great piece of chicken, not too dry..she thought the sauce could have been a bit more creative.

The dessert menu is ok but we were too full from dinner so did not get anything.

What makes this place stand out is the service and the feeling of the restaurant.  You can tell that the owner cares a lot, appreciates every party that comes in, and genuinely wants each customer to have a good experience.  Many of the customers when we were there greeted him by name and seemed to be regulars.  The staff feeds off him, and with it is a romantic/authentic dining experience.  

Lastly, try the specialty Italian sodas. Table next to us had a pitcher and they looked great.
author: Wayne H.

description: I rarely write on Yelp but I wanted to give a big thumbs up to this place. It is so unassuming - from the outside you wouldn't think its much. But the food is excellent and the staff are very cool. Its the kind of place you can celebrate a birthday with a group of friends or walk in alone, take a seat at the bar and feel right at home. I have done both. Tonight I was literally walking my dog, and was not planning to have dinner. I walked by and the staff were so friendly, I left my dog outside the front door and had an excellent meal and great wine, at the bar. Personally I think it does keep pace with the other high-end restaurants in the Pacific Heights neighborhood, especially for people who just want a low-key delicious meal in a friendly environment.
author: Cheri S.

description: Very good Italian restaurant.  I'm lowering the rating due to our experience. After checking out the wine list and finding it very well priced, we asked for a recommendation.  When the check came and we found out it was $110, it really turned us off.   Next time we will get the price before ordering!
author: Christine K.

description: A nice, cozy, Italian place on Fillmore - it's one of my favorite restaurants in this neighborhood.  It's always packed so it can be a challenge to get a table, but it almost seems like it's more fun to sit at the bar.  The entree portions aren't overly large - it's quality over quantity here.  They give you free bruschetta as a starter, and it was quite possibly the best I've ever had.
author: DD B.

description: The best Italian meal you will eat in San Francisco. I promise.
author: Danielle H.

description:
One of our go-to neighborhood Italian places.  Jack the owner seems to be there all of the time now and the food / menu / wine seems to have improved.  Service is not always "friendly" but they get the job done, don't take it personally.  

- great artichoke appetizer.
- rich creamy pasta dishes are good:  torellini al forno and gnocchi w smoked chicken.
-Elephant Ear chicken salad is really good.

This place is great for a quick dinner or if you want to come and eat a bunch, drink tons, and have a full meal.
author: Billy B.

description: Great place, try the Tortellino al Forno, VERYY good. The menu is a little limites, but the service was great, the mozarella entree was awesome and the complimentary bruschetta was a perk. Even with a bottle of wine, the tab wasnt too expensive.
author: Mercy G.

description:
reasons why i loooooove this place

1. they start everybody with a piece of the most delicious bruschetta
2. the food is simple but not typical
3. its REAL italian food
4. they serve semifreddo for dessert... my favorite
5. its about 50 steps away from the best view of the golden gate bridge (just a bit further down fillmore)

everybody who visits me in s.f. gets a trip to jackson fillmore and everybody loves it.  the only problem is the wait... no reservations for groups of 2, but you can almost always get a seat at the bar then.

go. now.
author: Venessa C.

description: Get the zucchini with almonds - amazing.  The bruchetta is awesome, and the snapper in spicy red sauce is really good.  OH and definitely the Fantasy cake - chocolate sex with zaballon.
author: Danielle B.

description:
I have never felt compelled to open a Yelp account to write a review until now - my experience with the staff at Jackson Fillmore was such that I need to share.

I made a reservation on Open Table for 8 people for a Sat. night dinner....now I realize the place is small so I called to double check that they could handle a party our size.  I was told yes.  They also called me about an hour and a half ahead of time to confirm, which I did.  We arrived at the restaurant about 5 minutes early and I see a large table in the corner and I think, perfect, we're all set.  When I approached the gentleman who was near the front and worked there, he literally waved me away when I spoke and completely ignored me.  Once I recovered from how rude he was, another gentleman approached and I tried to explain that we had arrived.
